WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SONIC BOOM in the crystal blue desert sky. A modified Bell Labs X-2 Ultrasonic JET -- basically a rocket with stubby wings that look more like vestigial fins -- SCREAMS upwards, an 80 degree climb into space. On its side is stylishly painted "Daedalus."

dialogues.speaker: ALTIMETER
dialogues.text: 108,999 FEET... THE "999's" roll over. The pilot's voice strains with the G-forces and thin oxyg

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 109,000. Come on, Frank, let's poke our nose into space. The pilot is Major WILLIAM "HAWK" HAWKINS, 26. In the seat behind him is MAJOR FRANK CORVIN, 29. Both wear bulky pressure suits and space helmets.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. That's enough, Hawk. We're approaching heat barrier. Let's level off. (into his radio) Recover One, this is Falcon. Beginning descent now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve miles below the X-2. Barrel-chested, buzz-cutted Captain "TANK" SULLIVAN is at the controls.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Roger, Daedalus. Got you on the scope, Frank. Tank sharpens the radar blip. As he does, we see a plastic hula girl on the instrument panel "dancing"  frenetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The altimeter hits 110,000. Frank and Hawk are breathing harder.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Bingo. 110,000th floor, ladies' lingerie. The DRONE of the rocket MOTOR HESITATES -- a nanosecond at most -- then RESUMES as normal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You catch that, Hawk? Hawk is in the zone, listening and feeling the airplane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hawk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain JERRY O'NEILL sits outside a USAF truck in front of a radar screen reading a Playboy magazine. He reads the copy aloud to himself.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Miss September, herself a promising student pilot, has a particular weakness for structural engineers with Ph.D.'s in astro- physics. He slowly moves the Playboy away and sees a scorpion climbing his bare ankle. He rolls up the magazine tightly, holds it above the scorpion, ready to swat it. He looks at the scorpion... he looks at Miss September's smiling face and airbrushed-breast... He can't do it, he can't sully this redheaded vision: He calmly grabs the scorpion by its stinger tail and flings it. Hawk's voice crackles over the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's alright, she's talking to me. You trust me, don't you, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Uh oh... here we go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the canopy -- the horizon -- the blue turns to  black. Hawk and Frank are touching outer space.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Frank, look. The full moon is rising over the curvature of the Earth.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (calm, faraway voice) That's where we're going. I don't know how, I don't know when... Frank looks up from the gauges at the horizon. He is mesmerized, speechless. Hawk starts to sing. Awesome pilot, lousy singer.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Fly me to the moon and let me play among the stars -- Frank looks out the window at the moon. The ROCKET MOTOR HESITATES AGAIN, SPUTTERS and GOES SILENT. All the gauges drop to zero. Engine failure. Frank is jolted back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Holy God. All we hear is the WIND buffeting the plane and the eerie sound of the plane's airframe and body skin CREAKING. Hawk works frantically to restart the engine, trying to joke through it.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hey, Frank, wanna get out and gimme a push?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch! They're nosing over, beginning what every pilot dreads most -- a flat spin. The cockpit ALARM SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: We have to eject.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: At 112,000 feet?! Are you outta your mind?!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: We're not gonna ride this thing out. Call Mayday -- we're popping!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (gasping for air) We are not... losing... another... ship!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spinning wildly, plummeting towards ground. The right wing shudders and rips away -- the plane inverts in its spin.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Don't think about it, Frank. Just do it. I'm gonna count down to one. Ready? One! Hawk yanks the T-handle. The explosive BOLTS BLOW the canopy off. Two screams, one of terror, one of joy, as they eject, the supersonic wind hitting them like a truck. Frank and Hawk are in free fall -- 22 miles over the desert. Approaching the speed of sound, they scream towards Earth. Frank is paralyzed in a still fall. Hawk tumbles and soars like his namesake, living every man's ultimate fantasy -- pure flight. Side by side, he seems to taunt Frank as he flies about. Frank pulls his rip cord at 22,000, arresting his fall. Hawk keeps right on going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, binoculars trained skyward, sees Frank's parachute deploy at exactly the moment he hears the thundering BOOM of the plane crashing into the desert floor,

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: That's gotta be Frank... but where's Hawk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk is soaring, spinning, laughing and screaming, ignoring the ground coming up quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tank searches through the windscreen for Hawk, when Hawk!-- a flailing flash, really -- free-falls right past the cockpit windshield, startling Tank.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Whooa shit!!  He banks the huge plane hard left to avoid hitting him. Tank grimly takes the dancing hula girl off the instrument panel, replaces her with a plastic dashboard Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand feet -- Mach one plus. Sluggish, lethargic, almost out. He wills his eyes open to see the ground coming up mighty fast and pulls the cord; the chute releases. A gut-wrenching force nearly yanks him out of the harness as he is pulled skyward -- 700 mph to zero in three seconds. He opens his face plate, gulping air, laughing like a schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry laughs, relieved, when he sees the second chute. He climbs into the truck, tosses the Playboy aside and STARTS the ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Crazy son of a bitch almost made like a bug on a windshield. Hawk touches down easily. He falls back on his chute, elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office of Major BOB GERSON, Air Force Special Projects Administrator. Only 27, Gerson already has the look of a polished bureaucrat. He looks out the panoramic window behind his desk at a thick, black column of smoke rising above the desert -- obviously the experimental X-2. SIRENS audible. His look is neither alarm nor concern. He studies the scene coldly and objectively like a scientist. And his eyes seem to smile, as though this is no real catastrophe to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank descends, he lifts his faceplate and looks out  at -- A column of black smoke on the horizon -- where the X-2 crashed. Frank touches down -- not quite as graceful or elated as Hawk. Matter of fact, he tumbles over, caught in the chute and rigging. A look of single-minded revenge on his face, Frank unharnesses himself and charges toward Hawk awkwardly in his stiff, cumbersome pressure suit. Hawk sits up, howls with joy.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: 112,000 and I feel fine! Let's do it again, Frank! Frank punches Hawk through the open faceplate of his helmet, knocking him off his feet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You always have to push things to their limit, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: That's what I do best, Frank. Frank dives on him, they lock up in a fight. Jerry jumps out of the just-arriving truck, and dives into the melee, trying to pull them apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank enters, literally hat in hand. Hawk follows him in, hat still on his head. Frank swipes it off, shoves it into his hands. The duty sergeant opens Gerson's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter, Gerson faces out his panoramic window -- we can still see the smoke from the brush fire caused by the crash of the X-2.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Is that smoke I smell? Looks like a fire out by Ridgecrest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We crashed the X-2.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: My four-million dollar X-2? Is that the X-2 you're referring to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did break both altitude and speed records, sir. And beat the free fall mark by 30,000 feet. Frank glares at Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Three planes in ten months. That's bound to be a record, too, Hawkins.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The engine failed. The aircraft went into a flat spin and we couldn't recover. Gerson nods "compassionately." No doubt that these two despise one another.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: (patronizing) But you made it. That's the important thing. (glances at his watch) And you made it just in time, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PRESS ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Crammed with PRESS people and photographers. They snap away, shouting questions to Gerson at the podium, flanked by Team Daedalus: Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank, who smile for the cameras. Gerson holds up his hand for quiet, and produces an envelope with the Presidential seal.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I hold in my hand an announcement from the office of the President. (reading the announcement ) ‘The United States' continued involvement in manned space exploration is hereby assigned to a new civilian agency, The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stration. Project Daedalus is now complete, and designated Mission Accomplished. He folds up the announcement. Frank is utterly confused.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER REPORTER, (PRESS)
dialogues.text: What about the pilots? Who's gonna be the first American in  space? Gerson turns to Frank, smiling. He slaps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: The selection has been made. After an exhaustive search we have identified who could best carry out this mission. (to the Team) This job calls for toughness -- physical and mental toughness -- and an ability to follow orders to the letter. Frank and Hawk exchange glances, wondering which it will be. Neither of them notices a sergeant walking in, holding the hand of...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: a three-foot chimpanzee wearing a NASA flight suit.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, meet Sam. The first American to cross into outer space. The chimp grins huge. Frank and the Team are open- mouthed, in shock. Gerson picks him up, smiling for the photo-op. The flashbulbs and questions erupt like a thunderstorm. Sam reaches his hand out to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Oh, look, Frank. He wants to shake your hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You bastard.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Shake his hand for the cameras, Frank. That's an order. Frank slowly takes the chimp's hand, looking as though he might be sick. The cameras flash more, blinding an already stunned man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing. SUPERIMPOSE: THE PRESENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's larger than a basketball and it's orbiting the Earth, it is tracked here. Pure NASA. Hi-Tech, all business. Five engineers sit at computers banging away at their keyboards in frustration. Astronaut/Engineer ETHAN GLANCE, 34, pushes back from the console. Ethan usually has the clean-cut swagger of an arrogant, handsome young man with too many letters after his name. Today, however, he's got the dishevelled look of a guy who's been up all night working.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It just isn't responding. The engineer next to Ethan turns to another engineer -- and translates in Russian to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engineers and administrators move about, focused, with a purpose. INT. OFFICE —- CONTINUOUS ACTION The sign on the door identifies this as the office of SARA HOLLAND, Space Shuttle Mission Director. Thirty- seven, ex-astronaut, focused like a laser beam on anything she pays attention to. Right now, she scans a thick computer printout, shaking her head at whatever it's telling her. The PHONE RINGS, she grabs it absent- mindedly.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Sara Holland. Okay, be right there. INT. NASA CONFERENCE ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER At the conference table sit Flight Director EUGENE DAVIS (60s), an avuncular, rotund man. Beside him are NASA administrators, a couple of STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIALS, orbital engineers, Russian engineers from Star City, and the Russian General VOSTOV (50s). Sara enters, arms full of files and printouts. BOB GERSON, now 67, quickly rises to meet her. Age has been kind to the retired General-turned-NASA Project Director: He at least has the appearance of venerability.  10.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is Mission Director Sara Holland. She's been closely monitoring the situation and she assures me the problem is well in hand. She looks at Gerson skeptically. Not the politician Gerson is, she begins her briefing, speaking a no- bullshit scientist's lingo colored with a hint of her Virginia heritage.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen. As you know, 11 days ago Atmospheric Tracking determined that Russian communications satellite Ikon has initiated orbital degradation. Computer trajectory models predict a steady acceleration in sequence with the gravitational constant.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Would you mind translating that for all the non-Ph.D.'s, Dr. Holland?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: The satellite's orbit is decaying, and the Earth's gravity is taking over. Vostov looks particularly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: There's a total systems failure in the on-line navigation and guidance avionics. All redundant systems are non-responsive. Without active course correction in the next 30 to 40 days, the satellite will reenter the atmosphere. Gerson looks nervously at Vostov.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: And crash?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: General, Ikon gave you fourteen years of service. That is within the performance range of a communications satellite. It will probably crash in the ocean or burn up in the atmosphere. I think it's best to let it.  11. Vostov stands, addresses the room conciliatorily.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: My country is grateful for the efforts of NASA and the State Department. However, losing Ikon is not an option. Ikon is not just a communications satellite to the Russian Federation. Ikon is the communications satellite. You are undoubtedly aware of our restructuring problems. Losing all telecommunications until we are able to replace Ikon could plunge us into chaos and perhaps even civil war.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Certainly you have other satellites aloft. Can't you transfer the workload?

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Gene, Sara; we have been given a Presidential mandate to assist the Russians... (smiling at Vostov) ++. Our partners in the International Space Station. (reassuringly to Vostov) We will fix this problem. It's just a glitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clearly pissed off Sara walks briskly behind Gerson down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You're feeding these guys bold- faced lies. This is a waste of money and a waste of my staff's time --

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You're a damn fine engineer, Sara, but you don't know shit about politics. Helping Russia save face is an act of good faith. You can't put a price on that. Gerson stops in front of a door and slides his ID key card through the electronic lock.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: Sara and Gerson enter. Ethan stares at his computer monitor, exhausted and defeated. The Russian engineers are slumped asleep on couches and at their consoles.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: This thing's dumb as a post. It's dead in the air.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Forget trying to talk to the satellite. You have the code, override the guidance system. Ethan points to four technical drawings pinned to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You figure that mess out. The guidance system on this thing is a dinosaur. Sara crosses to the wall, analyzes the technical drawings.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (nodding to sleeping Russians) Even these guys don't understand it, it's pre-microprocessor, it's pre-everything. Whoever designed this byzantine piece of shit is probably chopping rocks in Siberia.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (still staring at drawings) Is there anyone around who remembers Skylab?

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You're a damn fine politician, Bob, but you don't know shit about engineering. (turns to face Bob) This is the guidance system from Skylab.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: That's impossible. Maybe there are similarities, but they can't be the same.  13. Sara goes to one of the computers, logs on.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm looking up the designer.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Don't bother. It was Francis D. Corvin.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Is he dead? Gerson closes his eyes in dread.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Only if I'm lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Corvin's ranch house. An old Porsche 356 in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK CORVIN, age 69, has aged well -- strong, fit, and tan if a bit weathered. He stands on a step ladder installing an electric garage opener with a cordless drill. He's losing his patience, cussing under and over his breath as his wife BARBARA, an attractive, long-gray- haired woman of 65 refers to --

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTIONS
dialogues.text: which show the bearded assistant from "Home Improvement" grinning as he easily installs the device.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Would you like me to read you the instructions again -- ? Frank cuts her off with the LOUD CORDLESS DRILL at maximum revs. The final screw screwed in, he presses a button on the unit. The garage door goes down, smooth, perfect, the timed light goes on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let me explain something, darlin'. Job done, he steps down from the ladder, victory on his face.  14.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Those instructions are written by a Japanese fella in Japan where they make the damn thing. Then they have some expatriated American, living in Japan because he can't get a job in the U.S., translate them. Then, since it's Japan and they're wary of foreigners, they get a Japanese fella to edit the American guy who translated the Japanese guy. He grins smugly, takes the instructions from her, tears them in half. The timed light clicks off; it's pitch black inside the garage. We hear him fumble for the remote, and press the button. Nothing. He presses it again. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You know the door to the house is locked, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's just the security code. He pops the back off the remote --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Or the battery...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You forgot the battery?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (romantic) Well, looks like it's just you and me, in a dark place, the smell of gasoline and fertilizer in the air... He fumbles about, advancing on her. The ladder falls. She laughs, and "screams" for help.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Help! I'm locked in a smelly garage with a dirty old man! He stubs his toe, cusses. And laughs. She gives in, they start to make out. The GARAGE DOOR suddenly HUMS to life and opens, casting the daylight on them mid-embrace, revealing --

dialogues.speaker: SARA AND ETHAN
dialogues.text: standing in front of Frank's Porsche, a beige government sedan behind it. Ethan holds an identical remote.  15.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Corvin?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Doctor Corvin.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- Doctor Corvin. Am I interrupting something? The question is too stupid to even answer. Sara shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Doctor Corvin. I'm Sara Holland, and this is Astronaut Ethan Glance. We're with NASA. Frank eyes them suspiciously, looking at the remote control in Ethan's hand.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It was in your car. I heard someone scream.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thanks for saving the day. Now what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Could we have a minute of your time?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You should have called first. I'm a very busy man. Barbara stifles a giggle. Frank sends her a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Dr. Corvin, in thirty-five days a satellite with your guidance system on board is going to re- enter the atmosphere. The system is non-responsive. Want to take a crack at it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan has spread the technical drawings on the dining table. They all drink glasses of iced tea. Frank slowly crunches his ice as he studies the drawings. This clearly sends shivers down Ethan's spine, and Frank knows it.  16.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: There seems to be an interruption in the path here, but the circuitry is still operational. It's sending us data --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You've lost your uplink.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It has to be a problem in the manual routing drive here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: That's the consensus among the engineers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The same engineers that sent you here? He crunches his ice for emphasis. Ethan winces.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Does that bother you?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, it does, actually. Crunch.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Your design pre-dates all existing guidance systems. It was ahead of its time in '69, but this technology is obsolete now. None of the current engineers speak this language, and the older guys are... She trails off, the conclusion clear -- they're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It wasn't designed for this duration of duty. It was designed for SkyLab. My advice to you is capture the satellite and bring it home.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It's too big.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For the space shuttle? What kind  of bird is it?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's a Russian communications satellite.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What the hell's my guidance system doing onboard a Russian satellite?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: That's really not our primary concern at this time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Frank really hates him now) Where's it orbiting, or is that not a primary concern either?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: One thousand miles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Rate of decay?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: 8000 meters per day. And accelerating.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're right about one thing; that bird's coming home. Five weeks at the most.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: NASA's calculations agree. But here we are. Doctor, you designed this system. If anyone can solve this, it's you. Frank chomps his ice, sizing up both of them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For a moment there, I was thinking you two might be a couple of Bob Gerson's lackeys.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But judging by your command of the facts of history, I see that's impossible. He's been taking credit for that since I worked it out in '58, the year he replaced my ass with a monkey. His blood pressure's rising. He keeps his gaze on Sara, sees she looks uncomfortable.  18.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You don't work for Bob, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: He's a Project Manager at NASA. He's one of many people assigned to this problem. Frank nods, unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'll have to ask you both to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Corvin, your country needs you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Stick a sock in it, son. I've heard it all before. You can't solve this problem from here, and you'll never get a crew up to speed on it in time. Your bird's dead, let her die. My only hope is that what doesn't disintegrate during re-entry lands on Bob Gerson's house. Frank's rage boils right under the surface. Barbara watches from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But before you go, let me offer you both some career advice. Get as far from that son of a bitch as humanly possible. Ethan rolls up the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Apparently the buzz on you is correct.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And what buzz is that?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're not a team player. That's why you washed out at NASA.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of my house! Ethan exits hurriedly. Sara takes her time. There's disappointment, but respect on her face. She exits. Frank's face is flushed red, his eyes angry slits, teeth  19. clenched.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We have to brush up on your hospitality skills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence at the dinner table. Frank is still seething.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You know what the problem with that satellite is, don't you. Frank snorts, butters a roll. He obviously does.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You could fix it. Probably ina day. Right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I won't crawl back for another beating. Gerson made his bed, let him lie in it. Barbara. It's an old satellite, a Russian one at that. It'll burn up on re-entry and they'll build another one.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Frank... Barbara watches him leave, hates to see him like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes the original drawing of the guidance system out of a tube and spreads it across his drafting table. He blows the dust off it. He studies it, casually eating ice cream. The look on his face tells us the problem is obvious. His eyes travel up to --

dialogues.speaker: GROUP PHOTO ON WALL
dialogues.text: Team Daedalus in the '50s: Frank, Hawk, Jerry, Tank and a few other guys posing in front of the X-2 jet pre- crash. Full of youthful vigor, their dreams still alive, eyes on the prize of space.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FRANK
dialogues.text: staring at the picture. His eyes are misty; it's as if old dreams frozen inside him have begun to thaw. Like a  20. child, he licks the vanilla ice cream moustache off his upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks up from a classified Air Force file entitled "Project Daedalus." Frank Corvin stands at her door, wearing his cracked leather Air Force jacket and jeans, chewing gum.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I have a solution to your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Gerson looks up, sees Sara bring Frank in, covers his disdain with an insincere smile.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Frank Corvin. How long's it been?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not long enough, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Haven't lost that Corvin charm, have we? Coffee? Frank nods. Gerson goes to the credenza and pours a cup.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Sara tells me you're up to speed on our little problem. We've got one sick bird. (pointedly) Apparently there's a flaw in the guidance system. He hands Frank his coffee. Frank smiles at his jab.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's a helluva way to get the designer of that system to help you out.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Well, I heard about your initial  21. response. Don't worry, I'm sure we'll come up with something.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Dr. Corvin is here with a solution.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Well praise the Lord, we are delivered! Let's hear this solution, Frank. Frank's delivery is as nonchalant as possible.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Send my team up. We'll fix your broken satellite. Both Gerson and Sara look incredulous. An eternity passes. Frank fills the silence with a loud slurp of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You make a damn good cup of coffee, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You want to run that by me again?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Team Daedalus. Hawk, Tank, Jerry and me. Send us up.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: This is a joke, right? Frank grins impishly, shakes his head no. Sara resists smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We trained five years for a space mission.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: How old are you, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Old enough to know your ass is in a sling.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Sara, would you excuse us? This is fast becoming a personal matter. Enjoying this, Sara reluctantly exits.  22.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're out of options. I know that because I'm the last person you'd come to for help.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Your satellite comes down in thirty-four days. It's too big to retrieve. It's too important to let crash. I designed that guidance system. I'm the only one who can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: I don't know how to break this to you, Frank. But you're an old man.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, this old man's all you got. You know it, I know it. Besides, you let Glenn go up at 77. There's the offer. I'll be hearing from you. Frank stands, turns to leave. Gerson shouts after him.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You became a senior citizen five years ago! Frank stops, turns around with a care-to-differ look.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: For once in your life, be a team player. Train the crew if you like, but let the professionals at NASA fix the design flaw.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (getting angry) There aren't any design flaws. How it ended up in a Russian bird in the middle of the cold war -- that's the only flaw I see. How did that happen, Bob? Gerson squirms.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is a hands-on job, and there's no way I can train anyone in this time-frame. My offer's on  23. the table. Me and the team. Take it or leave it. He turns to leave again, walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You -- as a technical advisor, maybe. But I can't fill a space shuttle with geriatrics. You're professional enough to know that! Half those guys are probably dead anyway! Frank opens the door, and without looking back, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The clock's ticking, Bob. And I'm only getting older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank strides confidently to the front door. He's chased by a SECURITY GUARD, who grabs him. Frank pushes the man off him and keeps on walking.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY
dialogues.text: Mr. Gerson would like you to wait here. Frank stops, turns around. Gerson exits an elevator and walks briskly towards him. Frank grins confidently, hands in the pockets of his leather flight jacket.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Alright. It's a deal. He sticks out his hand. Frank looks at it, doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I want it in writing.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Okay. But here are the terms: you and every member of your team has to pass the same physical requirements as any other astronaut here. If one of you fails, none of you go up. (as Frank thinks, nods ) And just to insure this isn't a total exercise in futility, you will train to fix that guidance system side-by-side with my people in case your men don't pass, which  24. is a distinct possibility.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's fair.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how much I'm going to enjoy watching you make a complete ass out of yourself. Frank sticks out his hand, and they shake. Frank grins.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) It's great to be working with you again, Bob. Frank walks off. Gerson shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The Reverend Sullivan (Tank) pauses in his sermon -- puzzling over his notes. A youngish 67, his flowing robes can't hide his barrel-chest and Air Force tattoo on his wrist of a winged skull with a bloody dagger between its teeth. Tank is thoroughly lost, desperately trying to find his place, pages falling off the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Romans, uh... Chronicles... ah yes! The sparse congregation waits in catatonic silence. An old man, drool on his chin, jolts awake from his wife's elbow in his ribs. Sitting in the back of the church is Frank, barely containing his laughter at Tank's awkwardness in the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: ‘And in the fortieth year, Amariah begat Zadok, who begat Libni, the brother of Uzziah.' No... that's not it, either. Sighs from the congregation. Tank's losing them. He looks down at the face of the lectern at -- The hula girl we saw in his B-50 in '58. Keeps it there for good luck, and for moments like these.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, four of the best pilots in the Air Force trained to fly into space. They flew at the  25. speed of sound to the very top of the sky, cheating death as they freefall from twenty miles high. The church is waking up now -- they apparently love these old war stories from Reverend Tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The recessional music thunders as the congregation dismisses. Frank waits, smiling, at the end of the receiving line. Tank sees him, and grabs him up ina bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Boss. (looks up to the heavens ) Sorry. My former boss.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I bring glad tidings, Reverend Tank. They go by the name of Daedalus. There appears to be a resurrection after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot pictures among the seminary books. Frank reaches up and takes down a photo of Team Daedalus. Tank removes his robe, shaking his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I don't know, Frank. That's a complicated proposition. I have a flock. I have grandchildren.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They'll be here when you get back. Besides, you're bound to be able to milk this for three or four sermons.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I need to pray about this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can you pray quick?

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Wait... wait a moment, my stiff- necked brother... (closes his eyes, swoons ) I am receiving a word from on High.  26.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And what is this word? Tank opens his eyes, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: The word is, 'Why the hell not?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The park is under construction, empty except for cranes and crews assembling roller coasters. One of the roller coasters is completely built, and a single car rides around the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding alone in the car is Jerry O'Neill. Slight of build, a few wrinkles, a bad jet-black toupee under his baseball cap; at 68 he has become a swinging bachelor out of touch with the times. He grins ear to ear as he talks into a micro-cassette recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Let's kick this apogee up about 15 percent -- whoaa! Second bank's too fast, some little Johnny's gonna pass out on us... drop ita G going into third loop. (going upside down) Little more of a sine wave feel here... not so flat. Standing at the bottom of the roller coaster are several technicians and a PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN about thirty, watching Jerry, smiling. Frank walks up to her as he watches Jerry go around. He seems to know her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thirty-five years designing supersonic aircraft for the military. Now he's building roller coasters. Perfect. (laughs at the irony) Your father's a gifted man. The Young Woman looks at Frank, doesn't recognize him.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, he's gifted, alright. The roller coaster come in. Jerry gets out and hugs the  27. Young Woman, gives her a prolonged kiss that is anything but paternal. He sees Frank laughing to himself.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Frank Corvin! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just wondering if you're busy for the next month and a half. Jerry tosses his tape recorder to one of the technicians.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: NASA wants to send us into space. Jerry examines Frank, leaning in and tilting his head like Frank is crazy. He looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I wondered who'd be the first. Forty-year-old memories are sharp as the day they happened but you can't for the life of you remember what you had for breakfast. (pauses, loudly) What did you have for breakfast, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Vegetarian huevos rancheros and some kind of flavored decaf cappuccino that tasted like it was filtered through a jock strap. Jerry smiles -- his old friend is okay.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank proudly shows a copy of the NASA contract to Jerry. Jerry takes out a pair of very thick-lensed glasses ('80s Porsche frames) and puts them on. Frank's look of pride turns to one of worry as he sees Jerry's thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You need those?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: (without irony) Naah. They're just for reading... driving... seeing movies... walking. (at the contract) Frank, how on earth -- ?!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Are you in?  28.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Hell yes I'm in. Jerry hugs Frank, slaps his back.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Team Daedalus rides again. Hawk must've gone into orbit when you told him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I haven't talked to him yet. I haven't talked to him in a while, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: When are you guys gonna grow up and stop acting like little boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various aircraft ring a Quonset Hut next to this dirt field. The place houses a couple of flying schools, a crop-dusting outfit, and an Air Tours service. The YOUNG PILOTS inside the hut are all 30-ish, fresh out of the military, almost too serious about their work. An antsy kid named JASON enters excitedly with his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's my birthday. I want the shit scared outta me. You know, barrel rolls, loopdeloops... all that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PILOT
dialogues.text: We don't do that kind of flying. It's dangerous and irresponsible.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Too many lawsuits. Jason's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Well who does? The Young Pilot thinks, then points to the side of the Quonset Hut, which is open.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PILOT
dialogues.text: He does.  29. Hawk, now in his mid-sixties, sits unassumingly in a corroded aluminum fold-up chair, feet up on a cooler, reading a fishing magazine.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PILOT
dialogues.text: Hey, Hawk, this guy wants a scary ride. Hawk looks up, calmly eyes Jason who bounces on the balls of his feet in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Well, happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A P-51 Mustang does a 450 mph barrel roll 100 feet off the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back seat, Jason hangs on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: All right, let's go upstairs. The P-51's nose pulls straight up, and they're in a 6-G climb.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh God...!!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Here comes the fun part -- we're going weightless.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don't think that's such a good idea!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Aw, you'll love it. 10,000 feet up. The P-51 reaches its apogee, and gently noses over, her MOTOR WHINING down. As they go over the top, they go weightless.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh God!!  30.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: This is what flying's all about. Jason doesn't seem to agree. He's fully green, and gags.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I've had enough, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You sure? You got ten minutes left. (as Jason nods and groans) Whatever. It's your money. He throws the stick over, and Jason screams for his life as the plane plunges earthward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the windshield of his rental car, Frank watches the plane as it does a twisting, rolling free fall -- straight down. He recognizes Hawk's signature flying style, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk pulls out of the dive 100 feet off the deck again, pulling a snap-turn as he lines it up for the runway. Jason loses his lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P-51 gracefully hits the tarmac and rolls to a stop. Hawk CUTS the ENGINE, popping the canopy. Jason pours himself out, wobbly-kneed. Hawk, annoyed, helps the humiliated, still-green Jason out. Vomit is splattered all over the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Who gave you the bright idea to eat a big lunch before going up?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I'm so sorry, I'll clean it up, sir. Hawk reaches into the cockpit and pulls out a towel. Out of the corner of his eye, Hawk sees Jason's girlfriend bounding towards them from across the tarmac. Jason doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, I'll do it.  31. (loudly, so girlfriend hears) You earned your wings today, Hot Shot. I give. Hawk musters up a wink and a smile that fades the second Jason steps down to hug his girl. Hawk turns and wearily begins cleaning out the cockpit. In the b.g., Frank's rental car pulls up. Frank gets out, but Hawk doesn't immediately see him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey. Hawk looks up, no visible reaction.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hey. Frank walks closer. A long beat passes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You know what the worst day in my life was?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The day Armstrong set foot on the moon. I think I must've been the only person in the world who wanted to kill myself that day.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Thanks for that, Frank. We haven't talked in 12 years, and that was pretty much the big question on my mind. What are you doing here? Frank grins mischievously. He's been looking forward to this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Keeping a promise. A promise I made 40 years ago.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: The one where you were going to kill me on sight or just have my legs broken?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (smiles, remembering) The other one. I've engaged ina little blackmail with NASA.  32. They've got a satellite that's gonna crash unless they find a way to fix the guidance system.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I'm guessing you designed the guidance system.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (nods, grins) They're desperate. Bob Gerson came begging to me for help. I told him I'd fix it... but only if he sends up the original Daedalus team to do the job. Frank shows him the contract. Hawk studies it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's no joke, Hawk. Jerry and Tank are in; they're waiting for us at that roadhouse off the highway.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You know, age just brings out more of the Frank in you, Frank. I am genuinely impressed. Hawk laughs, Frank laughs, the two men laugh together -- this seems to be going well. Hawk carefully folds up the contract and hands it back to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Don't put foolish dreams in a fool's head. Especially not an old fool. Have a nice flight, Frank. Hawk goes back to the P-51's engine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You weren't a fool then. But you're being one now.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Say hello to Barbara for me. Frank stares at him angrily, his temper rising.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sure. Say hello to Jackie for me.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Wish I could, Frank. Wish I could.  33. Frank freezes, unaware that Hawk's wife had died.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't know. Hawk ignores him, continues checking the plugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He curses to himself as he drives along the highway. An old pick-up truck passes him on the left lane, nearly going headfirst into an oncoming eighteen-wheeler. At the last minute, the pick-up quickly cuts in front of Frank, kicking up a cloud of dust and exhaust in his face and tearing off. Frank angrily HONKS the HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's car pulls up and parks. He gets out and walks to the front door. He notices the pickup truck that just cut him off parked in the lot, and glares at it. Jerry and Tank open the screen door, stand in the doorway. They see the pissed-off look on Frank's face.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: He said no, huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let's get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Maybe we should talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Forget it. He's still the same stubborn, thick-skulled jackass he always was. Hawk, who has been sitting at the bar, turns around on his stool and finishes a beer. He smiles at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: And you still drive slower than a little old lady going to church. A smile slowly ripples along Frank's face. A DRUM ROLL and PATRIOTIC MUSIC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men of Team Daedalus, all wearing their cracked leather flight jackets, stride towards the mammoth NASA Headquarters, awed and dwarfed by its sheer size. The steps falter just a bit, the men wondering what they've gotten themselves into. They reach the giant front doors of the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twin glass doors open automatically. Frank enters, Hawk enters, Jerry enters, Tank hesitates. The biggest and toughest-looking of the bunch turns tail and starts to trot off when Frank grabs him and pulls him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our four heroes strut down corridor after windowless corridor of the interconnected buildings. Glances are exchanged between them and the younger men and women who make up NASA. The atmosphere is clinical, antiseptic, anti-heroic, and the people who work here are of the MIT- physicist-in-space mold. The two groups are a vivid contrast. More corridors. And more corridors. This place goes on forever. Jerry and Tank are getting a little winded. Tank, exhausted, sits down. Frank grabs his arm and yanks him back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tireless, hyperactive seven-year-old boy named ANDREW runs in tight circles, doing "airplanes" while making sound effects. This room is set up for tours and class trips; space suits and tools are on display. Sara talks to a group of kids, age six to ten, and their TEACHER. Sara obviously loves being around kids. Sara steps into a Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU) supported by a stand, wired up to a treadmill. The MMU looks like a giant chair-back with tiny jet nozzles and canisters of nitrogen gas.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is an M.M.U. That stands for Manned Maneuvering Unit. The M.M.U. allows our astronauts to move around in space so they can do work outside the space shuttle. Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank enter the room. Sara smiles  35. at Frank. The boy doing airplanes flies right into Tank's abdomen. Tank buckles over in pain. The kid ricochets off him, into Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Ooof!

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Andrew! Hawk catches the kid and lifts him up.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Come here, Andrew. Let's have some fun. She lowers the MMU down to him, and straps him in. She starts the treadmill. Andrew excitedly swivels the joysticks on the MMU's armrest controls. Gas sprays out from different nozzles on the MMU.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Just one little burst from these jets is enough to move the astronaut miles in space.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How come I'm not going anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because we're on Earth, and that's a very heavy unit. In space you don't weigh anything. There's no gravity, and there's no air resistance. The kids look fascinated but confused. Hawk holds his hand out, moves it up and down.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Like when you stick your hand outside the car window and the air moves it up and down. That's air resistance.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (smiles at him) Right. In space that wouldn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: So if I jumped on a trampoline in space...?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You'd go up... and up... and you'd never come down.  The kids giggle, loving this. Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry look as awestruck and thrilled as the kids.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Could you hit a baseball to the moon?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Actually, you could. All you'd have to do is knock it halfway there, about a hundred thousand miles, and the moon's gravity would do the rest. Hawk contemplates this. The teacher of the class herds the kids out of the room, leaving just Sara, Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I've never met a kid who didn't dream of being an astronaut when he grew up. Hawk throws his arm over Frank's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Ever met a kid who wouldn't let the dream go?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sara Holland, this is Colonel William "Hawk" Hawkins. Retired Air Force in 1990. Still the best pilot they ever had -- not counting me, that is.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Ma'am. He shakes her hand. Their eyes connect with a spark.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: The Hawk. I've heard of you. Commander Cliff Jenkins once told me a story about you and him in Viet Nam.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: It if came out of Cliff's mouth, I guarantee it's 100 percent bullshit. (laughs ) How is the old bullshitter?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: He's dead, actually. Hawk's smile freezes. Frank turns to Tank. 36.  37.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: While Hawk chews on his boot, we'll move right along. Captain ‘Tank' Sullivan. The best navigator the Air Force ever had, could find anything anywhere. That is, before God got him.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Now more than ever. Pleased to meet you, Miss Holland.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And last but not least, Captain Jerry O'Neill. Structural Engineer and designer. The Stealth Fighter is his drawing come to life.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You don't have a nickname?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: (kisses her hand) You can call me... ‘anytime.’ Big laugh. Frank rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: O-kay. Well, if you men are ready, we have some work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerson is alone with Vostov, who is pacing nervously.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: I don't need to remind you of the consequences of failure here -- personal consequences.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: That's the problem with you Russians, the glass is always half empty.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: These men you are sending up, they are not astronauts. The last time they trained for a space mission, people were driving cars with fins on them! Gerson laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Corvin isn't going anywhere. His team won't pass the physical trials.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: This is supposed to reassure me? What will you do then?

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: My best young astronaut is training alongside Colonel Corvin, gaining proficiency in this antiquated guidance system of his. Until he does, Corvin is to believe he's going up.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: (panicky) I don't know, perhaps we should consult --

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: There will be no consulting. No one is to be in the loop on our problem. Are we clear on that, General?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded room, filled with technicians, operations people, engineers, back-up astronauts, Gerson and Vostov. On the side wall stands Ethan and his team of astronauts: three men, two women... and they don't look too happy. Most pissed among them is astronaut ROGER HINES, 35, an athletic black man with a lot of attitude. The room goes quiet when Gerson and Sara bring in Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Good morning, all. Welcome to the STS-200 OPS overview briefing. All have NASA 3-ring binders, STS-200. That's the cue to open.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is a rather unusual mission, I think we'd all agree. We'll get started on the particulars here in a moment, but first I'd like us to make welcome the astronauts selected for this mission, the  39. founding members of Project Daedalus. Polite applause. Roger Hines' glare is withering.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: As all of you know these men are the pioneers of this business. They were around when rockets were born.

dialogues.speaker: SARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smile) Welcome, gentlemen. This is your team now. The door opens, and Flight Director Eugene Davis enters.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: STS-200 was originally slated to deliver a structural payload to the international space station. Circumstances have forced us to push back that mission and undertake an emergency rescue operation. Our average staging time for a mission is 12 months. We're doing this one in 32 days. (to Team Daedalus) The flight crew you are replacing is one of NASA's best.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You will train right alongside them in the interest of speed. Colonel Hawkins, you will be piloting the newest shuttle in our fleet. This is her maiden flight. Hawk looks at Frank with a devilish grin, whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You know how much I love flying a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You were the finest America had to offer once; I've no doubts you still are. Sara signals someone in the back and the lights dim. A 3-D map of Earth appears on a video screen. Jerry puts his glasses on. Frank reaches over and takes them off.  40.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: In 1986 the former Soviet Union launched communications satellite Ikon into orbit. Ikon is an irreplaceable link in Russia's telecommunication's chain. The graphic changes to a satellite with large solar panels.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Her orbit is decaying rapidly. She will enter our atmosphere in 30 days. Your mission is to intercept and capture Ikon, using the shuttle's grappling arm. You will then have a 42-hour window in which to repair the guidance system. From there, Ikon will be reconfigured from Mission Control. Once accomplished, you will return her to geo-sync orbit, using the Payload Assist Module rockets. The lights come up. Eugene Davis raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Question. (glances uneasily at Frank) With all due respect to Frank -- why don't we just capture the bird and bring her home with a team trained in satellite retrieval. It's clear that this is this question everyone here is wondering.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: It's too big, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: For the space shuttle? (to Vostov) How did you guys get it up there?

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: There were modifications post- deployment.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: The system has to be fixed on- site. Given the short time line, Frank, the only engineer proficient in such obsolete technology, is the only engineer who can do the job.  41. Davis is not convinced. Neither is Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis waits impatiently for astronauts, techs and Vostov to clear the hall before he dive-bombs Gerson, Sara and Frank.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: So Frank Corvin's taking his band of Leisure World Aviators for a ride into space. NASA agreed to this? The Russians agreed to it?

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Frank has left us little choice in the matter. Frank grins. Davis smiles cynically.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I figured it might be something along those lines. You two hate each other too much to cook this up together. No reply; it's obviously true. The smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I don't want any part of it. Get yourself another flight director. He turns to walk away, stops and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: By the way, how did the guidance system from SkyLab end up ona Russian Bird?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Damned if I know. But I seem to be the only one able to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Grow up, Frank. Be a team player. Help my astronauts out -- as an engineer!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If I weren't completely confident that I could deliver every bit as well as your astronauts, I wouldn't go near it. Davis waits, then lets out a soft rolling laugh from his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't changed a bit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That seems to be the consensus.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Gerson) I'm still the flight director, and I can pull the plug on this one. Frank smirks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: You guys made a deal, fine. But here's my deal. I'm not turning over a brand new shuttle to four rookies with a month's training. You're taking two of my guys with you. (off Frank's wince) Ethan's a brown-nosing brat, Roger's a cocky little shit, but they're the best astronauts in our pipeline. They're on board, or this flight stays on the pad.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: And if I sense for one second that you guys aren't cutting it physically or mentally, you're off and the original team flies. So let's see if you've still got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four naked male butts -- not exactly buns of steel. Wearing only their socks, Team Daedalus is lined up for hernia check. They cough, wheeze, and curl toes at the end of the doctor's cold, rubber gloves. They each step forward, moving on to --

dialogues.speaker: FOUR SCALES
dialogues.text: where they are weighed and have their height measured. Tank looks at his height, lets out a big laugh, turns to the straight-faced medical technician.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: All this high-tech equipment and your calibration is off! This  43. says I've shrunk an inch! He laughs, expecting the others to laugh with him. They don't; they just stare at him with pity. He gets the hint, stops laughing, stands as straight as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk, Frank, Jerry and Tank stand on treadmills, stationary. An annoying CARDIO TECH applies EKG tabs on to our bare-chested men, connecting them to EKG monitors. The tech talks to them like they are deaf, old men, enunciating very loudly.

dialogues.speaker: CARDIO TECH
dialogues.text: I'm going to start you off very, very slow. He points to a large, red button on each treadmill.

dialogues.speaker: CARDIO TECH
dialogues.text: If at any time you feel dizzy or weak, just hit the red button near your right hand. That will stop the treadmill He starts the treadmills, slower even than a walking speed.

dialogues.speaker: CARDIO TECH
dialogues.text: How's everybody feeling? Annoyed, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Maybe you could talk a little louder.

dialogues.speaker: CARDIO TECH
dialogues.text: Is that speed okay?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: No. It's not. Hawk presses a button on the treadmill that increases the speed of his treadmill so he's moving at a jogging pace. The others follow suit. The men get down to some serious exercise. Cardio Tech can tell he's not wanted, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL CLINIC
dialogues.text: Ears, throats, heartbeats are checked. DR. ANNE CARUTHERS, the flight surgeon, a pretty woman in her late 40s, examines Jerry's ear, and moves his toupee at least

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: an inch.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL CLINIC
dialogues.text: Hawk stands on a red line, Frank waiting next to him. Dr. Caruthers instructs Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: Place your hand over your right eye and read the chart if you would.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Time me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Huh? Frank, confused, looks up at the big clock. Hawk goes down the chart, reading incredibly fast.

dialogues.speaker: ,A,D,E,1,N,U,S,A...
dialogues.text: (laughs, fake modesty ) Oh, made in U.S.A. What do you know. Score one for the economy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: You have twenty-ten vision, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Uh, is that good? Frank yanks the joker away by his arm. Hawk takes a seat on a sofa a few feet behind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fourteen seconds. Time me. (a little slower) F,L,E,P,T,P,L,E,P,F,L,F,L,E,P,T,P,F..- I mean L... F... E... P.

dialogues.speaker: T.
dialogues.text: Frank shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: Twenty-twenty.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: And five seconds slow.  45. Dr. Caruthers smiles, amused by the competition between the two men. Jerry hands his thick glasses to Caruthers and steps up to the same eye chart Hawk read.

dialogues.speaker: EYE CHART
dialogues.text: It's a complete blur.

dialogues.speaker: ON JERRY
dialogues.text: Not even squinting.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: (shocked) You have twenty-ten vision, Captain. Hawk and Frank exchange baffled looks. Caruthers hands the smiling Jerry back his glasses. He saunters off. Frank walks up to him -- he doesn't even have to ask.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I may be blind, Frank, but I have a perfect memory. Always did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A needle comes out of Frank's arm. Dr. Caruthers quickly applies a cotton ball, closing his elbow. She hands the test tubes of his blood to an assistant.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: Next. Colonel Hawkins? Hawk sheepishly steps forward, dreading this. Sitting down, he turns away, not wanting to see.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: Are you feeling all right?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Not crazy about needles.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: That's very common. When was your last physical?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: A while ago. I couldn't say. She jabs Hawk, starts drawing blood.  46.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: You don't remember me, do you? My father was flight surgeon at Beal Air Force Base for 21 years.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Dr. Martin? The Goat?

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: 'The Goat.' That was my Dad. I met you when I was 12 years old, but that's been a while. I doubt you'd remember.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (studies her a moment ) Freckles, pigtails, knobby knees. Was that you? (as she grins, and nods) So how is the Old Goat?

dialogues.speaker: DR. CARUTHERS
dialogues.text: Passed away. Nine years ago. Hawk's smile freezes, again. She finishes, smiling sadly. And walks off with the blood. Frank and Hawk get up and go into --

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: both mulling over the same grim thought.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Are you noticing how everybody seems to be dead lately? They walk down the hall holding cotton balls to their arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn. Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank assemble out front in their NASA sweats, a humorous contrast to -- Roger, Ethan and the young team. They stretch. Roger not only touches the ground, he can palm it. Tank watches them, tries to stretch. He can barely touch his knees, goes as far as his ankles, hangs there, a distressed look on his face.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: (whisper) Hey, uh... Frank? Frank and Hawk are in good shape, stretch like pros. Hawk looks at Frank, tips his head towards Tank. Frank walks over and straightens Tank out. This hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: We'll start off easy today. Just do ten.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: (horrified) Minutes?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mile two. Astronaut Roger Hines leads the pack, doing about a five-minute mile, not breaking a sweat. Ethan and the rest of the young team right behind -- looking fit and invincible. About a quarter-mile behind them are!-—

dialogues.speaker: HAWK AND FRANK
dialogues.text: A little less invincible, but keeping a good pace. A few steps behind them are --

dialogues.speaker: TANK AND JERRY
dialogues.text: Red-faced, huffing and puffing.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I'm an engineer. I haven't run since Nixon was President. How far have we gone?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not quite two.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: This is gonna give me a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: That's the idea, Tank.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: What -- to give us heart attacks?  48.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Exactly. Imagine if we didn't make it through lift-off. The U.S. would be the first nation to launch four corpses into orbit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If we're gonna have heart attacks, NASA's gonna make damn sure we have them right here on Earth. So let's get this over with. Frank picks up speed, leads the pack. The others catch up. A grim pall settles over their morning run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger pushes 225 pounds easily off his chest, repeats it eight times with perfect form, Ethan spotting him. Roger finishes, slams the barbells against the rack, turning to Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Can you handle 225 pounds, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Sure. Hawk nervously turns to Tank.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Spot me. (winks, whispers) Spot the hell out of me. Hawk slides onto the bench under the barbells. Tank rests his hands under the bar, spotting Hawk. Hawk grunts as he pushes the barbell up. Roger and Ethan don't realize --

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: isn't just spotting, he's helping Hawk by lifting. The exertion shows in his clenched jaw, and the bulging vein in his neck -- he is straining not to grunt, must find a way to camouflage his exertion. He yells at Hawk, like a drill sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: PUSH
dialogues.text: Hawk (and Tank) successfully lift the barbell five times.  49. Roger and Ethan are none the wiser, look impressed. Tank is suffering. Tank finally lets the weight drop back onto the rack. Hawk slides out. Easy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Not bad. Roger looks at Tank, sees his face is red from exertion.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Man, you really get into it, don't you? Tank, suppressing a groan, gives Roger a weak thumbs-up. Hawk slaps Tank on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: (whispers) I'm gonna go to my room and cry now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full house. All crews breaking for dinner. Frank and the team bring their trays to a table reserved for them. They move slow and deliberately, obviously sore as hell. Creaks and groans as they fall into their chairs. They stare at the food, which includes corn on the cob, in exhausted silence.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I'm too tired to chew.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND ROGER
dialogues.text: sitting down with the young team. Looking over at our guys and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: sees the young team laughing. Cranky, he looks over his men.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Try and look a little perkier, guys. They manage some phony "perk," big smiles hiding big discomfort. Jerry has a few bites of corn.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I'm thinking now of my Uncle Wendell. The last ten years of his life, no one ever had a conversation with him that did not  50. center on his gout, his arthritis, or his bowel movements. (beat) I am beginning to see the world through Uncle Wendell's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You still sure about this, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We're almost done with the tough stuff and you want to quit? (looking his men over) Tomorrow we start training for our mission. I want everyone to get a good night's sleep.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Boy, there's a challenge. Something catches Hawk's eye. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Jerry, what are you doing? Jerry fiddles with his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: It's these damn teeth. (he adjusts them) They won't stay in. Frank is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Jerry. Hawk laughs. The waiter walks over holding a tray with four cans of Ensure, the power drink for seniors.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. A round of drinks from your friends at the table over there. Ethan, Roger, and the young team laugh as they raise their coffee cups to them in a toast. The room goes quiet, awaiting their response. Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank raise the cans to their hosts, and clink them together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (loudly, to the room) To old farts in outer space. The room fills with laughter as they drink up happily,  51. deflating the intended insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three A.M., pitch black outside. Frank dozes on his bunk, glasses down his nose, STS-200 binder on his chest. A RUSTLING sound wakes him. He looks over, sees --

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: quietly dressing in jogging sweats.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Too much for you, huh? Decide to quit while you're ahead? Hawk laughs as he puts a T-shirt on.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Thought I'd start the day with a little jog.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? We jog at five and it's only three. Go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You want to sleep, Frank, sleep. You look like you need the rest anyhow. The gauntlet down, Hawk opens the door to leave.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pitch-black out. Hawk jogs around the track --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: right next to him, wondering how he got conned into this.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: SAME SCENE -— DAWN Hawk and Frank, still jogging around the track. Sweaty, but looking strong.  52.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I'll race you the last lap.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hawk... okay.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Countdown to one. Ready...? (beat) One. Hawk bursts forward, Frank right after him, two old men racing like schoolboys.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK AND FRANK
dialogues.text: running, neck and neck, the sun coming up behind them. The grounds' sprinklers burst on.

dialogues.speaker: IN PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sara gets out of her car, walks briskly to the administrative offices, all business, until she sees --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK AND HAWK
dialogues.text: finish the race in a tie, then fall on the grass, exhausted. They sprawl on their backs underneath the sprinklers to cool off.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: smiles to herself as she watches. A new feeling is coming over NASA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, holding a manila envelope, tentatively walks up to the men's locker room door. She listens to FRANK AND HAWK TALKING from inside. The door suddenly opens, surprising Sara. Frank steps out, fully dressed, looks at the embarrassed Sara with a smile. She gathers her wits.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank. I'm looking for Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He's inside. You can go on in.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Is it... okay?  53.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (with a twinkle in his eye) Oh yeah. He walks off. Sara enters the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara enters, looking around, hears Hawk humming. She passes a row of lockers, looks behind it (we don't see what she sees) -- and instantly turns on her feet and walks back to the door, her face beet red.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. Hawk comes out from behind the lockers, towel wrapped around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: It's okay, it's okay. (as she stops) So. What brings you to the... men's locker room, Sara?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (difficulty concentrating) Gene moved up -- he moved up the simulator run. She trails off, nodding. Hawk looks at her, waiting for her to finish.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: To... when?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Right. That would be... eleven o'clock. There are some new procedures I wanted you to be aware of. She hands him the manila envelope. Hawk opens it and takes out several pages, which he carefully reviews, totally nonplussed by the situation. After a long, awkward beat, Hawk stares at her and smiles. She returns the smile weakly.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is extremely uncomfortable. I'm going to leave now. Hawk gestures grandly to the door. He smiles, watching as she hurries off.  54.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hey, Sara. I'm taking you out for a beer.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (to herself) I'm going to need one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a full-scale mock-up of the space shuttle. Tank sits in the payload area holding the grappling arm control joy stick in his hand. He faces a monitor showing a simulated satellite in space. Six stoic engineers in white coats watch him as he tries to capture the satellite with the grappling arm. He looks disturbed that he is being observed so closely.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: You're making me nervous. A FEMALE ENGINEER leans forward and whispers in Tank's ear.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ENGINEER
dialogues.text: You should probably get used to it. There's going to be a lot more people watching you on television. He gulps, misses the satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of blood in a stand. Dr. Caruthers takes a drop of blood from one of the tubes and sandwiches it between two slides. She examines it under the microscope, focuses. She looks concerned. She takes one of the test tubes out of the rack and puts it in --

dialogues.speaker: BLOOD CENTRIFUGE
dialogues.text: She turns the centrifuge on and the test tube goes whipping around and around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The massive arm swinging around the circular room slows to a stop. Two TECHS pop open the clear canopy and unfasten Jerry and Tank from the two seats. They're a little shaky as they exit the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: That was three G's. That's as bad as it gets during ascent and entry.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I'm so pleased. Hawk and Frank are up now. They eagerly jump inside the cockpit, and get strapped down, hooking up their headsets. The canopy closes over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: First one to pass out buys the beers tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're on. Frank grabs the joystick and off they go, whipping around 1G, 2 G's... They reach 5 G's in no time.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (over communicator) Hey, Frank, did we start yet?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (into communicator) I don't know, feels like we're standing still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Engineers look aghast as the boys crank it up some more. Other crew people enter the room, including Roger and members of the young team.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (shaky voice, over monitor) What's the matter, is the damn thing broken? This is a spectator event now. They're up to 8 G's. The room shakes.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON HAWK AND FRANK'S FACES
dialogues.text: shaking and warping out like the science book pictures.  56.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (really shaky) Hey, Hawk, I'm pretty sure the machine just kicked in. Hawk cranks it up some more. And some more. This is getting serious.
