dialogues.speaker: HAWK AND FRANK
dialogues.text: are beginning to "gray out," but neither will say "uncle" first.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Yyyyou're... e-e-easy... Fffrankkkk... 10 G's. The MACHINE is SCREAMING. The room is silent.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: They're gonna kill themselves.

dialogues.speaker: HERE
dialogues.text: Everyone turns around. Davis, at the back of the room, steps forward and slams the "all stop" switch. The arm slowly winds down. Everybody is totally busted -- young and old alike -- just by being here. The arm stops, but we don't see anything through the canopy from inside the booth. Davis is seething -- grabs the intercom microphone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I'm sure this was a great show. But this thing is not a toy! (into the intercom) One of you idiots care to explain this?!

dialogues.speaker: CENTRIFUGE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: As the Tech lifts the canopy we see that Frank and Hawk have both passed out. With their flush red faces, drool at the corner of their mouths, and their sweaty hair, they look like sleeping babies strapped into car seats. The Tech takes their pulse. They groggily start to regain consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: They're just unconscious, sir. Davis fights it, but his scowl gives way to a smirk... then a smile. The entire room looks relieved.  57.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I'm getting too old for this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is crowded with young professionals at happy hour. Hawk and Frank shoot pool. On the dance floor, a small group of pretty young women, led by Jerry, are line dancing. Tank stands alone drinking a beer looking around the room. He sees something that draws him like a bug to a light -- An arcade game -- the kind where a joy stick operated claw-on-a-crane drops down and picks up a stuffed animal inside a glass booth. Tank beelines towards the game and drops in two quarters. He swigs the last of his drink, then takes the joy stick.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Purple tiger. The crane comes to life as Tank maneuvers the joy stick left and right. It drops over a little stuffed purple tiger. Tank gingerly clamps on and guides it over the chute, dropping it. Tank joyfully retrieves his little stuffed animal and starts laughing goofily. He looks around the room to see if anyone saw his victory. No one did. He stops laughing and stuffs it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: OVER AT HAWK AND FRANK'S POOL TABLE
dialogues.text: The pretty young COCKTAIL WAITRESS brings over two bottles of beer. She puts them on a narrow counter near the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
dialogues.text: That'll be seven dollars. Frank and Hawk just look at each other, a stand-off -- neither goes for their wallet.

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: He's buying.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh no. We passed out at the same time.  58.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Bullshit. I watched you pass out. (beat) Right before I passed out. They crack up. Hawk reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I got this round. Only because I'm so confident in my superiority to you in every aspect of human life. Frank stops Hawk from paying.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe there's a way to settle this. (turns to the Waitress) Given the choice, which one of us would you take home with you tonight? She plays along, looking them over.

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You mean like, to 'the home'? Like the retirement home? Onlookers laugh. All except a big, tough man named TINY.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: No, seriously. Would you choose this man, with his asymmetrical sagging ass cheeks, love handles the size of Nebraska, and yellow ingrown toenails.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Or this man, with the chicken- gizzard neck and the face that looks like a Death Valley fire road? The woman's charmed. She's about to answer when Tiny intercedes.

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: Stop harassing the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm not harassing anyone. I was asking her a harmless question, one that's got nothing to do with you. So go back to nursing your virgin peach daiquiri and mind your own damn business.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: It is my business. This woman's my friend, and she puts up with assholes like you all day because she has to --

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Tiny -- Hawk mouths to Frank, in disbelief, "Tiny?"

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: -- but I don't. So if you want to harass someone, start harassing me.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I do believe he is, son. Onlookers laugh. The man isn't pleased.

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: I could put you in a hospital, old man.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I've got Medicare. Take your best shot. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: I don't want to make your old lady a widow. This overheats Frank's core. Frank drops the charm, his temper flares. He grabs Tiny and shoves him against the counter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What did you say? Tiny pushes Frank off him, gets in fighting stance. Frank rips his leather jacket off, pulls up his sleeves. Hawk has obviously seen this happen before, rolls his eyes as he steps between the two men and addresses Frank's opponent.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Excuse me a minute. (to Frank) Listen, Frank. You can't do this. We're going up into space in 25 days. Hawk speaks loudly enough that the crowd around them hears their conversation about "going into space." They  60. seem like loons. The crowd includes one man drinking at the bar with a camera bag and notebook.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: If you hurt yourself, if you break a bone or sprain an ankle, your seat on the shuttle is going to that M.I.T. weenie with the blow- dried hair. And we all watch it on TV at your house.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who said I'm gonna hurt myself?

dialogues.speaker: TINY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you two talking about -- 'the space shuttle'? Hawk holds up his finger to Tiny for more time.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You're going to blow it for us again, aren't you? You and that mean-assed temper of yours.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You still think I blew our shot in

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Face it already, Frank. You did. Tiny loses interest in fighting Frank. This suits Frank fine -- Hawk is now the subject of his wrath. Tank and Jerry watch from the sidelines, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Here we go again. Frank shoves Hawk. Hawk retreats, not wanting to fight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And the pilot who wrecked every rocket and experimental jet the Air Force gave us? Frank shoves Hawk again. Hawk let the first one slide, but not this one. He pushes Frank back, grabs Frank's jacket off the pool table and throws it in his face. Frank catches it.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Let's take it outside. I'm gonna kick your asymmetrical sagging ass.  61. Hawk and Frank storm out of the bar. Bar patrons watch the two men like they are crazy. All except the man at the bar with the camera bag, who scribbles something in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE HONKY-TONK
dialogues.text: Hawk and Frank step out the swinging doors into the parking lot. Frank seething. Hawk laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: How'd you like that? Can I still get you out of a jam or what? You see that guy's face when I said, ‘space shuttle' -- ? Crack! Frank punches him hard in the jaw. Hawk hits the pavement, rubbing his jaw, realizing Frank wasn't in on the plan.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Whose fault was it that Daedalus got canned, Colonel Hawkins?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Shit. This is gonna be a long night. Hawk gets up, punches Frank in the face. The two go at it like this, duking it out in the parking lot, bobbing and weaving, neither one relenting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eugene Davis walks down the hall. He passes --

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: walking toward him, head down because he's reading a file as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Hawk. Hawk looks up long enough to show us his black eye.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Morning, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to your eye?  62. Hawk keeps on walking.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I fell in the shower. Maybe you could have maintenance install some rubber no-slip adhesives on the floor, it can get pretty slippery in there. Davis knows he's being bullshitted, lets it go. He enters the --

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEERING LAB
dialogues.text: Where Frank works on a mock-up of the guidance system with Jerry. His BACK is TO Davis and us. Ethan watches as Frank touches two separate electrical buses with probes. Jerry alternately watches a monitor while screwing something in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's that doing?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Still ten megahertz. Little more.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: How's it coming along, Frank? Frank turns around; he, too, has a black eye.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Pretty good, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: What happened to your eye, Frank? You slip in the shower?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How the hell did you know? Frank slowly gives his most charming grin. Davis turns his back on it and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, alone in the room, pedals on stationary bike while reading the manual to Frank's guidance system, frustrated. His arm band heart MONITOR BEEPS. Gerson walks in.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you in my office in a couple of days. I'm starting to  63. worry.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You should worry. This guy won't let me within ten feet of him. I'm not even sure he knows how to fix the guidance system; he just wants a free ride. Gerson shuts off the bike, Ethan stops pedaling and the BEEPING STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Ethan, maybe it's time you and I took a look at the big picture. There are six slots on the first Space Station crew. There are fourteen partner countries and all of them will want to send up one of their own. Some of those are bound to be women. You're a pale, stale American male. Consider the odds.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I'm confident in my abilities.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Well let's see if you can't apply those abilities to Frank's guidance system. Your efforts won't go unnoticed. Gerson starts the bike again and we hear Ethan's HEARTBEAT RACING. Gerson smiles, satisfied, pats Ethan on the shoulder and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTED RUNWAY
dialogues.text: The shuttle is on final approach to Cape Kennedy, coming in for a night landing. We're actually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Ethan at the controls, Frank and Hawk observing in the seats immediately behind. Pace is fast and furious -- all business. Gauges flashing everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Gear is down and locked. Airspeed 300. Cross-wind on our right, 14 knots.  64.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: We're a little hot. Dropping flaps.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: 200... 100... touchdown. The virtual shuttle rolls to a stop. Roger turns to Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You're up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is humming. These flight engineers train right along with the astronauts in the simulator. Sara watches the big screen with Eugene Davis.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Nice landing, guys. Let's put our rookies up front. SimSupe, you on with me? INT. SIMULATOR CONTROL ROOM —- THAT MOMENT The Simulator Supervisor (SIMSUPE) answers.

dialogues.speaker: SIMSUPE
dialogues.text: SimSupe. Go, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Standard package -- throw a little curve at ‘em, though.

dialogues.speaker: SIMSUPE
dialogues.text: Roger that. He punches up a program on the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk and Frank at the controls. Same scene on the simulator screen. An ALARM sounds as they approach the runway.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hydraulic failure. Right aileron.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Switching to manual control.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You can't do that, Colonel. The bird's on a computerized track.  65. Another ALARM.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Airspeed's too high. Come on, Hawk, stick to the protocol. Go around.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: We'll never make it. Switching to manual. Ethan shakes his head no. The runway approaches rapidly. Hawk pulls back on the wheel -- no response.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You can't do that!! Roger grabs onto the seat arms as though they are really about to crash.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Damn it! Prepare to abort!!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Like hell. He fights to hold the wheel -- it's a rough, nearly sideways touchdown -- the shuttle bounces once, twice...

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Awww... shit. And its gear collapses as it crashes down, tumbling over. The screen goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence in the room. Davis looks up at the blank screen, calm, but obviously very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Come on, Gene. You can't throw all that at him on his first run!

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: We've got three weeks, Sara. And this is Flight School 101 stuff. (shakes his head) He's been out of the game too long.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SIMULATOR
dialogues.text: Ethan and Roger show professionalism, but their eyes show satisfaction. Hawk and Frank stare straight ahead --  66. both angry and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (whispers) This isn't your P-51, Hawk. You gotta do it their way.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I don't need a damn computer to land an airplane, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Sir, it's not an airplane. It'sa flying brick on approach and you've got to work with the on- board computer.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: And if the on-board computer fails?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It's never failed. Hawk glances over at Frank -- sees how disappointed he is.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (into communicator) Houston, S.T.S-200.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Request second landing. (thinks ) Request also computer failure on approach.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Say again, 200?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole room waits. The CAPCOM (the voice of Mission Control) turns to Davis. As does Sara. She pleads with her eyes. He relents with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: All right, run it again.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM
dialogues.text: S.T.S-200, stand by for second  67. approach.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Throw the works at him.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Emergency night landing into North Africa. Wind, rain, very rough.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Altitude 3000. You're coming in too steep, Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You better pull up, sir. You're gonna lose it again! Hawk ignores them. Another ALARM sounds.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Auxiliary engine fire -- number two! Shut it down. Hawk calmly hits a sequence of switches, never taking his eyes off the approach.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Don't need it anyway. We're just a flying brick from here on in. (smiles to himself) The flying brick... He hums to himself, totally in his element. The shuttle buffets wildly -- the radar ALARM sounds now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wind shear on the nose. All the computer screens go blank. Ethan gloats.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Computers are down, sir. She's all yours. Hawk doesn't even notice.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Sara is worried. Looks like a repeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: focused on the runway coming up, still humming calmly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Altitude 500. Lined up.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Your airspeed's way too high.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Airspeed four-nine-zero. That's too hot, Hawk!

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You'll never get this thing stopped!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Aw, it's easy. You just gotta tap the brakes. He gently nudges the nose up.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You can't do that! You're gonna put her into a stall! The stall ALARM sounds. The wings can't support the weight at this speed and attitude.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: 100 feet. Hawk, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Tapping the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Drop the nose! You're gonna lose it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: 50 feet! Drop the nose!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Airspeed?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (shocked) Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: What do you say we drop the nose? He nudges the wheel over gently. Touchdown. Light as a feather.  69.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: They watch in shock as the shuttle rolls to a perfect stop. Davis is open-mouthed. Sara yells out loud.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Alright, Hawk! She can't believe she did that, looks around, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SIMULATOR
dialogues.text: Roger is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: For a computer, maybe. He gives Frank a signature Hawk grin.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: The Flying Brick. I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner. Ethan, Roger, and the young team look up as the Waiter arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, from your teammates at the table over there. He busily hands out a tray full of Gerber baby food jars, barely keeping a straight face.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: And some training material for you to look over... He hands out a stack of Curious George Goes Into Space books. As the room erupts in applause and laughter, Ethan and Roger turn slowly to... Team Daedalus -- They raise their cans of Ensure and clink them.

dialogues.speaker: TWO BEER BOTTLES
dialogues.text: clink together.  70. Hawk and Sara sit side by side on the hood of her '65 Mustang convertible, the Houston city lights below them, the moon shining bright above them. He takes a sip of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Forty percent.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Forty percent?! That's the best you'll give me?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (grinning seductively) You might nail it. You might crash and burn. The odds are against you, Colonel. With a twinkly smile, he puts the beer bottle on the hood and turns to her, looking like he's about to make a move on her. Instead, he bends down and picks up a rock off the ground and lets it fly, hitting a telephone pole a hundred feet away.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (mockingly) Forty percent.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: The wind was with you.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: The wind!? She laughs and hands him his beer.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Forty percent for you, you nail it. Forty for me, I would've missed by a mile. (sips her beer) That's why I moved out of the astronaut program. The odds of me getting on a shuttle were nowhere near forty percent. But I was an astronaut. Yes, I was.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Damn right, you were. They clink bottles, then toast the moon.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You don't think like that, do you. You jumped out of planes twenty miles up, drove rocket sleds the speed of sound -- you're not afraid  71. of anything.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: No, that's not true. I've been afraid.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Bullshit. When.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (thinking hard) Well. When I was seventeen. God, I was crazy in love with this college girl. She was gorgeous, a real ball of fire and crazy in love with --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (wearily) You.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: No. A&M's All-American defensive end. Scott LeBeau -- man he was six-six if he was a foot, and Gary Cooper handsome. One night some friends and I had a few too many of these... (shakes his beer bottle) «+. and we crash this big ol' sorority cotillion, everyone all dressed up in chiffon gowns and Daddy's tuxedo. And there's us looking like three hobos that just fell off a boxcar -- and this is at the governor's ranch, you see.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm getting the picture.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: So my friends see Scott LeBeau entering the outhouse, right? (takes a deep breath) Well, I did a better tackle on that outhouse than he'd ever done on the football field, rolled that sucker right down an embankment into the creek. There's screaming and crying the whole way down -- only it doesn't sound like an All-American defensive end. It is decidedly more feminine than that.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you didn't.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: The love of my life, slip-sliding away. My friends were pretty funny guys.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Ran like hell, joined the Air Force the next morning. She playfully shoves him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You were afraid Scott LeBeau was gonna kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hell no, I was afraid of her. Laughing, they stare into each other's eyes. After an awkward pause, she makes the move, kissing him.

dialogues.speaker: ON HAWK'S FACE
dialogues.text: He's enjoying the kiss, but something is wrong. He kindly withdraws from the kiss, then hugs her. Sara looks quizzical. He stares over her shoulder, smiling, his thoughts far away.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I married her four years later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry run as a tight-knit group, keeping a good, strong pace.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEWHERE IN TREES, (OVERLOOKING GROUNDS)
dialogues.text: The man from the bar hides in the bushes, aiming his telephoto lens at the men, clicking off pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara arrives to work a little late, so she adds a little jaunt to her step. Co-workers stare at her from their cubicles with prying, pitying eyes as she passes. She gets a little self- conscious.  73.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What! I'm only fifteen minutes late. Someone tosses her a copy of USA Today. The headline says: "THE RIPE STUFF." Underneath is a big, grainy spy picture of Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank running on the track in their NASA sweats. They look good. Inset is an old photo of Team Daedalus, the same one we saw in Frank's garage.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Holding the paper, she makes a bee-line for her office. She opens the door and goes --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE HER OFFICE
dialogues.text: where Bob Gerson is sitting in her chair. He is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Extra. Extra. Read all about it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Bob, I don't know how this leaked out --

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: NASA is getting calls from every tabloid and TV show in the country asking me to verify this story. Sara weighs this.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Why can't we verify the story?

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: S.T.S.-200 is a delicate and top secret satellite recovery. This looks like a three-ring circus. How do you suppose the Vice President felt this morning when he sat down for breakfast, opened his paper and saw this? He opens the USA Today; there is a full-page grainy spy photo of Frank and Hawk, post-jog, shirts off and sweating, looking good for 70-year-old guys... but they're still old guys. Sara emits a quick burst of laughter, chokes it back.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: I have to face him, Sara. You  74. don't. He furiously throws his newspaper in the garbage and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside is the shuttle simulator. It sits propped on a frame, with stairs leading to the cockpit hatch. Eugene Davis escorts Frank, Hawk, Jerry, Tank, Ethan and Roger, all wearing their flight uniforms, up the stairs. A technician opens the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: This is a full-scale simulator of your cabin. Except for gravity, we're going to simulate living conditions on board in order to familiarize you with your new living environment. Bon voyage. The men enter the hatch to the shuttle. He shuts the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger demonstrates proper urination/defecation tools and technique for Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry. Roger holds up a clear funnel, speaks in a humorless deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: This is your funnel. Attaches to the hose here. Before starting up the hose, you want to make sure you have a tight seal against your skin. Jerry raises his hand, an impish smile on his face. Roger looks at him, knowing the question he's about to ask.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Yes, one size fits all. Jerry lowers his hand. The others chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Just in case, you also have a diaper under your pressure suits. More chuckles from our heroes. Roger remains poker- faced.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: The men go about the simulated mission in the shuttle:

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: runs systems check with the on-board computer.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: practices capturing a mock-satellite with the robotic grappling arm.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: The men eat "space food" while they work.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: A call comes in.

dialogues.speaker: SARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (dripping with irony) Dr. Corvin, this is Mission Director Sara Holland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distressed Sara holds a copy of People magazine with a posed photo of Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank on the cover, all wearing their leather flight jackets with NASA caps.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm having what my ex would call a Salmon Day.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A ‘Salmon Day'?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You know, when you feel like you've been swimming uphill all day just to get screwed in the end? I am looking at a copy of People magazine with a picture of you and the boys on the cover. You wouldn't happen to know how this happened, would you? Frank and Hawk laugh.  76.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let's see. They called me up on Tuesday. I met with them on Wednesday, I answered a few questions, they took a few photographs --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Frank, you have to clear this kind of stuff with me first. Are you aware of the impact this is going to have?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'd have to think that when you put four old S.O.B.'s on the cover of a magazine, it's gonna drop magazine sales pretty bad. The techs around Sara laugh. She just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAY LENO does his monologue.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Did you read this? NASA is training four guys in their late sixties to go on the next shuttle mission. I'm not kidding. So far, NASA's biggest fear is that these guys are gonna spend the entire launch doing 50 in the left hand lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off light laughter) Brand new shuttle too. They had to make a few modifications, though. Like putting phone books on the seats so the astronauts can see above the wheel... Behind Jay, Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank appear from behind the curtain, wearing their leather flight jackets. The crowd applauds wildly. Jay thinks it's for him.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Everybody at NASA loves these guys, they're very popular. Okay, there have been a few complaints from the ground crew. Apparently these guys keep putting those 'My grandchild is an honor student' bumper stickers on the back of the  77. shuttle, and the ground crew has to keep scraping them off... Frank eggs on the crowd with a thumbs down. The crowd starts to heckle Jay. Frank and Tank lift up Jay, "surprising" him, and they start to escort him off the stage.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Stick around. We've got Sandra Bullock, Buck Owens, and these guys!

dialogues.speaker: "TONIGHT SHOW" SET
dialogues.text: Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry sit on the couch next to Jay.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Forget all this Right Stuff crap -- let's cut to the chase. I understand one of you is just a machine with the chicks... (looks at Hawk) Gotta be you, sir. Hawk shakes his head, points to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Jay, it's like I tell these clowns, you can't just know what a woman needs, you have to know what a woman wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching it on TV, laughing hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And you, sir. Is it true that you are a Baptist Minister?

dialogues.speaker: TANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's right, my son.

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And your name is Tank? A preacher named Tank? Tank rolls up his sleeve, shows his new tattoo -- a cross with rocket exhaust coming out, headed for the stars. The audience loves it. Sara's PHONE RINGS. She ignores it, letting the MACHINE ANSWER. GERSON leaves an ANGRY MESSAGE. She turns the TV VOLUME UP to drown him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two NASA T-38 TRAINER JETS SCREAM by. Hawk and Roger practicing more approaches, each in his own jet, talking by radio.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Follow me, Colonel. We're going to come in at forty degrees. This simulates the attitude of the ship on glide slope.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Flying Brick...

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After you, Rog.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Please don't call me 'Rog.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger, 'Rog.' Roger, annoyed, takes his jet in. Fighting it, he sets the plane down for a bumpy landing... then lights the AFTERBURNERS into another take-off roll, climbing hard into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Lines his jet up, humming to himself. And just to make it interesting, does a Snap Roll with the jet at 500 feet before taking her in for a perfect Touch & Go. He lights the AFTERBURNERS and the JET SCREAMS skyward in a vertica climb.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Something like that?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (impressed) Yeah. Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can I call you 'Rog' now?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. You can call me 'Rog' now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Neutral Buoyancy Lab. A giant pool where the astro- nauts train for weightless work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Jerry, and Tank in cumbersome space suits, do repairs on a mock satellite. Divers stand by alongside. Ethan is at poolside, on headset, observing the procedure on the video screen looking frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The lead is connected here, across the relay.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You're a genius, Frank. Frank gives the divers a thumbs up. Frank, Jerry and Tank are lifted out of the water by cranes. Once out, techs help them removes their helmets. Ethan walks over.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: So the relay patch is the key?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Plain as the nose on your face.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How did you by-pass the heat exchanger?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn't by-pass anything.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're not being very forthcoming on the workings of the guidance system --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I've tried everything short of calculus lessons to get you to understand this thing. What do you want me to do -- draw you a picture, connect the dots for you?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I hold two Masters Degrees from M.I.T., Dr. Corvin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'd get my money back.  80.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Ethan, you've been trained on a different set of technologies. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (ignoring Jerry, to Frank) You're compromising this mission. I'm your backup. I am on a need- to-know basis.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You don't need-to-know shit. And I don't need a backup.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. More than you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) What is that supposed to mean? Ethan realizes too late that he's said too much. Frank looks suspicious, paranoid, furious.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What don't I know? (as Ethan holds his tongue) What don't I know?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerson is in a tele-conference (via video feed) with a Suited Man appearing on a laptop computer which sits on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: SUITED MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let me spell it out for you, Bob. P-R spells bud-get. Frank bursts into the room, pointing a finger at Gerson.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're setting me up again!

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Here's one of our astronauts now. Frank, what a semi-pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You sonofabitch! You had no intention of sending me up.  81.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Frank, I'm in the middle of something just now. Frank angrily slams Gerson's laptop shut, terminating the call. Gerson smiles smugly.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You just hung up on the head of our program, the Vice President. So what can I do for you, Frank? Frank quakes with anger. Red-faced, snorting loudly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You had no intention of sending me up, did you?! You screwed me over in '58 and you're screwing me over now -- !

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Screwed you over -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You lied to me again. How could I be so stupid as to make a deal with a chronic liar?!

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Deal, Frank? You blackmailed me. I didn't make any 'deal' with you. But whatever you want to call it -- you lost. I don't have to send you up. Frank looks confused. Gerson hands Frank a printout of a lab report. Frank looks it over; it makes no sense to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know what this shit means.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: It means someone didn't pass his physical. One of you has cancer. Frank goes white, tentatively turns the page over of the lab report, sees in cruel, military typeface: "HAWKINS, WILLIAM B." Frank's mouth goes dry.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: It's his pancreas. And it's inoperable.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Does he know?  82.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Dr. Caruthers told him this morning. Frank shakes his head, getting angry again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. I don't trust you! This is bullshit! He tears up the lab report, throws the scraps on Gerson's desk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I want independent tests done by independent doctors -- not ones you bankroll to lie for you and print up bullshit lab results! (catches his breath) This is low, even by your standards. Just to keep me from going into space. Gerson smiles smugly.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Oh, that's what this drama is all about? And this whole time I thought it was Hawk, your friend. But it's really your seat on the space shuttle, isn't it? You can rest easy, Frank. NASA is still sending you, Jerry and Tank up on the shuttle -- regardless of the ‘deal' you and I made.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You're front page news, Frank. A real American hero. You've made NASA popular all over again. Thanks to you, they're gonna get that juicy budget infusion they've been drooling over. Oh, you're going, Frank. The Vice President insists. Gerson opens up the laptop, prepares to reconnect.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Now if you'll excuse me, I have to call the head of our space program back and apologize for the interruption. Like a zombie, Frank wanders out of the office.  83.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE GERSON'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Frank wanders down the corridor, lost in painful thought. People greet him as they pass, but he doesn't hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across from the space center complex. One of NASA's and the Air Force's storage garages. High-performance aircraft are lined up silently and eerily still, as though waiting.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT TO SR-
dialogues.text: is Hawk, dressed in civilian clothes. He walks the plane silently, deep in thought. As he ducks under the fuselage, he sees --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: watching him walk the plane. The obvious doesn't need to be said.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: This was my Blackbird. I retired this very airplane in '90. And here she is.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I've never actually seen one before. Hawk smiles like a proud parent showing off his kid.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: SR-71. This is what a plane's supposed to be. She's ugly on the ground, leaks like a sieve. But up around mach one, her seals all expand, she dries up and leans into the wind and goes like hell. I took her right to the edge. 128,000 feet. He runs his hand along the plane's skin, softly, reverently.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: She's only happy up there, goin' fast. She's not meant to be sitting on the ground. That's a lousy way to die. Sitting around, waiting...  84. (pauses) Eight months. That's the best I can do, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: They don't know that for sure. There's chemo. Radiation.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I watched my wife go out that way. I ain't taking that road. She nods, making sense of the other evening.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (softly) The love of your life.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) Where the hell is the pancreas, anyway? I don't even know what the damn thing does beside give you cancer. They share a weak laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: What odds would you have given us?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Better than forty. She smiles coyly. He kisses her and they hug.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: approaches tentatively from the other end of the hangar. He sees Hawk and Sara break out of the hug and say a few words. Frank stops and waits respectfully. Sara walks away from Hawk, passing Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sara. Frank approaches Hawk, can't find the words.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Frank. I know how much this flight meant to you. Looks like I crashed another one. I'm sorry.  85. Frank dreads what he has to say next.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They still want to send us up. Me, Jerry and Tank. Hawk thinks on this, smiles slowly.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Well, that's great, Frank. You played these guys perfectly. (off Frank's worried look) You said yes, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Don't be an ass, Frank. Don't blow it a second time -- this is your last shot!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This isn't easy, Hawk...

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Easy? Don't whine to me about easy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Put yourself in my shoes --

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Oh no you don't. You've blamed me for Daedalus for 40 damn years! You're not laying this one on me! You choke this one, it's you. All you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What would you do?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I'd leave you behind in a heartbeat! Frank's temper starts to cook -- which is just what Hawk wanted.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You would, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: To go into space? Bet your ass, boy. In a heartbeat. Hawk turns on his heels and walks off. He stops and  86. spins around.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You know what the worst day in my life was, Frank? The day I met you and you put the idea in my head that I could pilot a ship into space. He turns and walks off. Frank watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mammoth hangar is the height of a thirty-story skyscraper, but we can't tell from this angle. Frank shows his clearance badge to the SECURITY GUARDS at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: How can I help you, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I just wanted to go inside and have a look.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Everyone's left for the night, tomorrow's roll-out, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's okay, I want to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (opens door) By the way, I thought you might find it funny: My daughter has a photo of you on her wall next to Leonardo DiCaprio.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And why would I find that funny? Frank winks, pats the guy on the shoulder. And goes -- INT. VEHICLE ASSEMBLY PLANT —- CONTINUOUS ACTION We STAY TIGHT ON Frank as he walks across the expansive floor, looking up at something. (NOTE: This is the biggest enclosed space in the world, but we don't get the sense of that yet.) Frank sits down on the floor, props himself up against the wall. He sticks a piece of bubble gum in his mouth, chews, blows a bubble as he looks up at it...  87.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: FRANK — LATER in the same position, only sound asleep. An enormous MOTOR WHIRS as daylight streams across Frank's face. His eyes squint open, and he looks over at the light, coming from --

dialogues.speaker: MIGHTY CONCRETE DOORS
dialogues.text: rolling apart, letting in a slit of light a foot wide and thirty stories high. The light hits --

dialogues.speaker: SPACE SHUTTLE
dialogues.text: sitting on its enormous roll-out platform. Rays of sunlight play on the brand new titanium skin and protective tiles. She's positively gleaming in the morning sun, her fuel tanks and solid rocket boosters dwarfing everything around it, including --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: who stares up in awe at it. The ground crew stands by proudly, preparing for roll- out. A CONSTRUCTION TECH sees Frank.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTRUCTION TECH
dialogues.text: Sir, are you here for roll-out?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. He gets up and strides out of the hangar, passing through the slowly-expanding slit of the concrete doors and onto the crawler-way as the one MPH roll-out begins behind him. The ground crew looks at him strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara talks with Gerson. Frank enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm not going. Not without Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: You're blackmailing me again, aren't you?  88.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. I'll teach Ethan everything he needs to know. But I don't go up without Hawk. Frank turns around and exits. Gerson turns slowly to Sara.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Next idea, Miss Holland?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You know, even with the cancer, Colonel Hawkins passed all his physicals. There's really no reason he can't fly the mission. Especially with a back-up.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Frank Corvin is going to put me in the nut-house. Sara holds back her smile, runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks to the front door. He knows he's done the right thing, but it hasn't brought him any joy. A SECURITY GUARD grabs his arm. He pushes the man off, keeps on walking.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY
dialogues.text: Colonel Corvin, Miss Holland would like you to wait here. Frank stops, turns around. Sara exits an elevator, breaking into a wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Team Daedalus -- all of Team Daedalus -- has a launch in 92 hours. Let's get rested and prepped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE TECHS, Sara, and Davis in a huddle. Very serious, looks of dreading and foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is a problem. Somebody has to deal with it.  89.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Don't look at me. I'm not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: I'm not doing it either. Sara looks pleadingly to Davis.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: No way. I'm not trained for this. I'm just the flight director. Sara winces.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Across the room, in their spacesuits, holding their helmets. A last minute helmet fitting. Sara enters, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Jerry, can I talk to you in private?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Sure thing, pretty lady. They walk over to a corner where they can have some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Now how can I be of service? Sara hesitates with dread, can't look him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's your toupee, Jerry. You're going to have to remove it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What toupee? Sara stares at him blankly, doesn't know what to say next. He gives her a coy wink.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: But I'll get a haircut if you like. STEVE MILLER's "Space Cowboy" thunders in as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Female engineers swoon, whistling, giving high-fives to!--! Jerry swaggers down the hall in his blue NASA astronaut jumpsuit, zipper down to his chest, gold chain dangling, a Stetson on his head. He does a disco twirl and removes his hat to reveal his shiny pate -- he has totally shaved his head and pierced both ears.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Come on girls, give it up for the space cowboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-dawn launch. Team Daedalus, Roger and Ethan go through the final suit-up and preparations. Quiet, thoughtful, nerves in evidence -- a pre-game, locker-room feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is humming with activity. Engineers at their stations, Sara flips through computer spreadsheets. Eugene Davis barks through the checklist procedure through his headset -- every answer coming over the COMMUNICATOR is "GO."

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: P.C, Guidance, Cape Flight, .S., L.R.D...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open, Team Daedalus comes out -- to the applause and cheers of --

dialogues.speaker: SMALL CROWD OF PEOPLE
dialogues.text: standing on the other side of a cordon. The crowd is a select one -- Frank's wife Barbara, members of Tank's congregation, Jerry's girl friend, Roger's wife and kid, Ethan's mother. The astronauts walk to a cordon, about 15 feet from their loved ones and shout their goodbyes. (NOTE: The unintimate goodbye is necessary to keep the astronauts from getting contaminated before boarding.)  gl.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Barbara) Why are you so nervous?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (what a stupid question) Why am I nervous. Husband and wife stare at each other. Barbara looks to Frank's right, signals for Frank to look at --

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: He stands there, silently watching everybody else bidding farewell to their loved ones. The loner, he is the only one with no one to say goodbye to, but doesn't seemed bothered.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You bring that man back alive, Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: It's against my better judgement, Barb, but if that's your wish, I'll honor it. They all laugh, say final goodbyes and board the NASA van

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The space shuttle, poised on the pad, glowing in the beacon lights, clouds of VAPOR SNORT out as she is fueled -- this ship is alive, waiting for them. The van stops. The men exit and pause -- letting their eyes travel to the top.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hot-damn, Sam... that's a bird. Tank points to the side of the shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Well I'll be. Printed on the side, the name of the new shuttle: "DAEDALUS." The men smile in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nice touch. INT. TOP OF TOWER - WHITE ROOM —- CONTINUOUS ACTION  92. QUALLS, the launch safety officer, awaits -- giving their pressure suits a final check. He's as nervous and excited as they are, just not as skilled in hiding it.

dialogues.speaker: QUALLS
dialogues.text: General Corvin, General Hawkins, welcome to Daedalus.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We're only colonels, Mr. Qualls.

dialogues.speaker: QUALLS
dialogues.text: I'm just sayin' it like it oughtta be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are brought aboard the now-vertical ship, one by one. All business now, the techs and flight engineers strap them in, seal their helmets, and get their oxygen and communicators up and going. His job done, Qualls pauses at the round hatch, his eyes glistening, face beaming with pride.

dialogues.speaker: QUALLS
dialogues.text: You're good to go, men. See ya back on the ground, Team Daedalus. He slams the hatch shut. The men stare straight ahead, listening as the BOLTS SLAM into place and the airlock seals up. Then a deafening silence. Not on-line yet, they sit in a moment's contemplation. Looking at one another, realizing this is it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe a prayer is in order. Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I was just reciting the Shepherd's prayer. (beat) Alan Shepherd's prayer. All smile -- even Roger -- and together recite Alan Shepherd's famous pre-launch prayer on his 1961 Mercury flight.

dialogues.speaker: TEAM DAEDALUS
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, please don't let me fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear. And laugh and applaud, a great tension  93. breaker.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Very appropriate, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a human being in sight. Just space shuttle Daedalus -- fuel tanks filled with 4.5 million gallons of liquid hydrogen and oxygen, breathing steam, barely held to the gantry. Ready to go. As the VOICE of the LAUNCH CONTROL OFFICER (LC) commences the FINAL COUNTDOWN...

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: is aglow with the instruments and screens.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: performs the final preparations and checks. Cc) CAPCOM continues his monotonous checklist of NASA three- letter acronyms.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: Davis's check is complete. He settles into the flight director's chair, watching the big screen with Daedalus on it. Sara puts her print-out aside.

dialogues.speaker: LC
dialogues.text: T-Minus 15 seconds. The room goes still. This remains the most tense moment of any mission -- no one has forgotten Challenger around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gallery of family, friends and officials joins in the countdown... Silent, awestruck. INT. SHUTTLE —- THAT MOMENT  94. FLASH TO each of the men of Daedalus. Faces serious, anticipating. Hawk's is more like a kid's -- awaiting his ride on Space Mountain. Frank's shows just a hint of anxiety...

dialogues.speaker: LC, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 9, 8, 7... ignition sequence begin. We have main engine start.

dialogues.speaker: ROOF OF CAPE HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: The night sky is lit up for miles as the ENGINES ROAR to life. The SHUTTLE SHUDDERS from the force, "twanging in" 40 inches towards its liquid hydrogen fuel tank.

dialogues.speaker: LC, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 3, 2, 1... and lift off. Lift off of space shuttle Daedalus, and S.T.S.-200. And the mighty ship slowly, majestically rises, shaking off her tethers. Shuttle Daedalus is on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunderous applause -- but all eyes remain riveted to the screen as she clears the tower.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Go get ‘em, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoved hard into their seats as they go from 0 to Mach 1. Hawk war whoops with delight as the shuttle rolls over in her inverted flight attitude.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Houston, this is Daedalus. Roll program.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger roll, Daedalus.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Omigod...!!!

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: (laughing under the G's) Thank you, God.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Daedalus, you are go at throttle up.  95.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roger, go at throttle up. He fights the G's to turn to look at Hawk -- who is just waiting for the command.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Pull the trigger, Hawk. Hawk grins, and throws the throttle up.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stand by for separation of S.R.B.'S...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roger, Houston. Standing by... 3, 2, lees A THUNDEROUS EXPLOSION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOLID ROCKET BOOSTERS IGNITE, FIRING DAEDALUS out of the stratosphere and into HYPER-SONIC speed. INT. SHUTTLE —- THAT MOMENT

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: S.R.B.s are gone.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger, Daedalus. You are negative return.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roger, Houston. Negative return. (to Hawk) We're a dot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness returns. Space shuttle Daedalus is now just a tiny pinpoint of light, high in the pre-dawn sky -- heading east towards the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17,100 MPH, in Earth orbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston, this is Daedalus. Do we have a go for orbit OPS?

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger, Daedalus. You are go for orbit OPS. Good work, guys. They remove their helmets and watch them float away. Frank unbuckles and pushes off from his seat, followed by the others. They float about the cabin, weightless, tumbling, goofing like kids. Except Ethan: he's all professionalism and seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: stares THROUGH the window on one side at the vivid blue and white earth beneath him, small, tangible. Smiling, elated, he looks over his shoulder at --

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: staring THROUGH window on other side. Hawk looks at the moon -- and it is huge and bright. Hawk looks back at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: It was worth the wait.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was. Hawk holds out his hand. After a beat, Frank grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Frank. I owe you one. They reel each other in, the handshake becoming a meaningful hug between two old friends. Roger floats up to Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Not a bad take-off, for a rookie. You're over now. (off Hawk's puzzled look) Over the edge. You're in space. Welcome to the club. Big grin, big slap on the back. MID-DECK —- LATER Jerry tries to prepare himself a snack, fumbling with the galley equipment. Frustrated as his afternoon snack takes flight in the weightless compartment. He attempts  97. to retrieve it.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Let's get ready, everyone, we have a live global broadcast in two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the rest of the team can be seen on a giant TV monitor. Eugene Davis, Sara, Barbara Corvin and WALTER CRONKITE stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves his finger down, a signal to Cronkite.

dialogues.speaker: CRONKITE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Colonel. When Frank speaks, his lips are curled around his gums and he sounds odd, like he has no teeth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Good morning, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: CRONKITE
dialogues.text: Well I guess the question on everyone's mind is: how has age affected your ability to command this shuttle so far?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As you and I know, Walter, age is a very overrated factor in determining one's capabilities... As Frank talks, a pair of dentures floats by, between Frank and the video camera. He reaches out and grabs them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've been looking everywhere for these. A tense moment at Mission Control, until Frank uncurls his lips from his teeth and grins. Whooping laughter from the entire room, including Sara, Eugene, and Cronkite. Barbara, Frank's wife, covers her face in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No. I didn't just see that.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the crew So long, The camera's light himself in Frank's stare into the video camera.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: everyone. goes from green to red. Ethan puts face, mighty pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: 'That' was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Not funny. Half the world was watching us, we represent the best America has to offer. Why can't you act your age? Lighten

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: up, peachfuzz. Take a moment and enjoy yourself, you're in space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the far corner, Gerson and General Vostov huddle in conference. Vostov is sweating nervously.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Four hours to intercept. We're right on schedule.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: That's not what I'm worried about. Relax. them.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: Our man is up there with

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT DIRECTOR'S CONSOLE
dialogues.text: Eugene Davis monitors the situation. Sara, on headset, talks to the payload engineer on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Okay, Daedalus's got Ikon on the scopes We should have a visual momentarily.  99.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Stand by for terminal initiation burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk and Roger gingerly guide the shuttle towards an object on the radar screen. Work mode now, the crew is getting set to grab Ikon.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Range 5,000 meters.

dialogues.speaker: TANK AND JERRY
dialogues.text: In the crew cabin, operating the capture control. They stare at a tiny dot on the video guidance screen. Tank sweats it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Roger, Hawk. We've got a visual here.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Standing by for a 15 second burn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let's go ahead and deploy the arm. Tank operates a joystick, focusing intently on the screen. No smiling and joking now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shuttle's grappling arm unfolds from the open cargo bay.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Deploying the arm. 2200 feet, dead center. Good driving up there, Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let's light 'em up. Hawk cranes his neck to see the satellite growing nearer.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Stand by. T.I. burn in four, three, two, one...  100. He hits a glowing switch. The shuttle's orbital maneuvering ENGINES FIRE, slowing them down on the line to satellite Ikon.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Hello, Ikon. And how are we feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Activating secondary radar and floods. Roger flips two switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shuttle hits Ikon with a flood light. Suddenly, like an origami flower unfolding into a dragon, the satellite slowly transforms into something very menacing looking. It morphs and grows, modules coming out of modules. The solar panels fold back like the ears of an attacking dogs. It slowly rotates to face the shuttle. INT. SHUTTLE —- THAT MOMENT Frank stares through the bay window. His mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Dear God... Roger hears SOMETHING on the RADAR.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Holy shit, this thing's trying to get tone on us!

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: It's painting a target on us. It thinks we're a bogie. Kill the radar. Roger flips OFF the RADAR. They wait nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It completes its rotation, facing the shuttle. We can see painted on the side of Ikon the faded letters

dialogues.speaker: "C.C.C.P."
dialogues.text: INT. SHUTTLE —- THAT MOMENT 101. A tense beat passes. They all stare through the cockpit window.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: We're okay.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: No wonder the damn thing's orbit is decaying. It's gotta weigh 50 tons.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fire the retros, Hawk. (into headset) Houston, Daedalus. Do you see what we see?

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger, Daedalus. We're studying it from here. Stand by for a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis, in deep thought, watches Ikon on the screen along with everyone else in Mission Control.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Does that look like a communications satellite to you, Sara?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (turns to Vostov) General, what kind of modifications have your people made here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: There's just so much stress that grappling arm can take. Vostov stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: It's within operational limits. Tell Frank he can latch on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Frank stares out at the cockpit windows, mesmerized by Ikon.  102.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That is the damnedest thing I ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: It must be fitted with some kind of self-defense mechanism. The radar must have activated it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can you grab it, Tank?

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. I can reconfigure. I'm just worried about the mass.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm worried the damn thing's gonna get pissed off again.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Tank, you're gonna have to latch on without any radar assist.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Tank's gonna have to do what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know about this.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: The objective of this mission is the restoration of this satellite. Let's get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm not getting my crew killed -- and that includes you. (into communicator) Houston, Daedalus. We're still standing by.

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Daedalus, this is Houston. You have a go for capture.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roger, Houston. We copy. Okay, guys, let's grab it and have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk has maneuvered the shuttle to within 10 feet -- the grappling arm extended.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger turns to Hawk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Is he as good as you say he is?

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Tank? He's da man. Tank is in The Zone. He moves the arm with robotic precision.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Drifting left, Tank! That's too far!

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Hail Mary, full of grace, holy shit! I got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grappling arm contacts the satellite, and locks on.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: You da man, Tank.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: I da man. High fives all around. Even Ethan is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Ethan and Jerry do a final hook-up in their space suits and MMUs (Manned Maneuvering Units). Roger looks them all over, nods his approval.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Man, you boys look sharp. He exits the airlock. The SEAL on the door HISSES as it opens and they float into -- EXT. SPACE —- CONTINUOUS ACTION

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over radio) Welcome to space, Frank. You've waited a while for this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Only forty years.  104. They rip around like George Jetson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone watches Frank jet around the satellite in his MMU, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This feels kinda like that '43 Buick you used to drive, Gene. A little slow around the curves, brakes don't work for shit.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: All right, cowboys, let's herd 'em up. We do have a job here, you know. And they approach Satellite Ikon. Jerry latches his MMU to the side of the satellite next to the panel. Ethan hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Ethan float inside a long, narrow cylindrical compartment inside the satellite; they are deep into the repair. Several control panel plates float freely, the circuit patch boards exposed. Frank throws a switch inside a control panel. Pinpoint lights fade on inside the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay, we've got power now. Let's have a look at the brains. Frank goes to open a new access panel with his cordless drill.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Frank. I don't think that's the panel. Ethan is below Frank, couldn't get to Frank's access panel in the cramped quarters if he wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerson and Vostov watch the goings-on anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the cordless drill Frank unscrews the last sheet metal screw, removing an access panel. In the shadows of the compartment, Frank sees a long cylindrical object.  He aims a penlight at it. Its tip is bullet-shaped, the tail disappears into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Abort activity.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What is it, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Frank, listen to me --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I said, abort activity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In decompression. They remove their helmets. Frank is confused, and furious.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ethan, what the hell is going on here? What is this damn thing?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: A Russian Communications satellite, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Bullshit! You think I don't know a nuclear launch platform when I see it?! Why the hell are we helping the Russians put a missile silo back into orbit?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're some kind of genius, you figure it out. Frank shoves Ethan in the chest hard. He flies backwards into the bulkhead.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're only here as a publicity stunt. You got what you wanted, you're in space. Now finish the mission! Frank looks duped and unhappy about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis, Sara, Gerson and Vostov look up at Frank on the video screen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay, Frank. This is a secure line.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You have good reason not to want this bird to fall, Gene. It has six armed nuclear warheads onboard. Davis turns to Gerson, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: What's he talking about? Gerson looks as incredulous as everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: I have no idea. (to Vostov) General, is there something you'd like to tell us? At first Vostov looks betrayed, then faces Sara and Davis.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: Ikon is a relic from the cold war. It has floated dead in space ever since the Soviet Union fell. There are six missiles onboard targeted at strategic American installations. All, most regretably, in large metropolitan areas. If Ikon goes off-line it will assume that there has been a catastrophe and will initiate launch on its own. The silence is deafening.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You picked a helluva time for a confession, General.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: (indignant) Those are our men up there. This is a treaty violation. A big one.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You bastard.  107.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You know, it's really touching, Bob -- your concern for our safety and all. While you're at it, Maybe you could ask the General how my guidance system for SkyLab ended up on this six-gun. Gerson squirms.

dialogues.speaker: VOSTOV
dialogues.text: It was stolen by the KGB from Mr. Gerson's personal files. Sara and Davis look at Gerson, shocked. Gerson acts aghast.

dialogues.speaker: GERSON
dialogues.text: This is all new to me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'd hook us on to this bastard, put it back into orbit fully armed, and keep it a secret just to save your own ass?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: People, we have a real problem to deal with. We don't have time for this now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks morose. Hawk kills the transmit switch.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Huddle. We got a big-ass problem. We're locked into a 20-megaton hydrogen bomb going 17,000 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jerry, how high can we send this shitheap? Can we get it into deep space?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: With three Payload Assist rockets? Just. Maybe. I don't know. The "AIRLOCK OPEN" light blinks, accompanied by a BUZZER.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What the hell's that? Hawk floats to the side window, sees Ethan, in the MMU, floating towards the satellite, towing the Payload Assist  108. Modules (three four-foot-long rockets strapped to an aluminum pallet) with a tether. Frank furiously shouts into the communicator.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ethan, what are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your job, Frank. I'm putting Ikon back into geo-sync orbit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're doing, Ethan! Get back here! (on no response) Ethan -- !?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, propelling himself towards Ikon, flicks OFF his RADIO, cutting off Frank. He reaches Ikon, latching his MMU to the side of the satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank goes to the airlock door.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Frank, he jammed the airlock door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Open the panel and override it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan unbuckles the rockets and removes one. The other two float freely next to him in space. He starts locking the rocket in place on a circuited bracket on the belly of the satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank talks into the communicator.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ethan! Do not lock-on the P.A.M. rockets, do you read me!? (urgent, to Jerry) How long?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I almost have it, Frank.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan locks the first P.A.M. rocket in place. As he clamps it down, it suddenly FIRES a SHORT POWERFUL BURST -- The satellite lurches on the shuttle's arm, twisting it, heading right towards the shuttle. INT. SHUTTLE —- THAT MOMENT The SATELLITE CRASHES into the BULKHEAD with an ENORMOUS BOOM! The bracing and shelving collapses under the weight and on top of Roger. He is slammed to the floor, head bleeding badly. Pandemonium. Pressure leak starts, oxygen escapes, a fire in the aft crew compartment. Team Daedalus reacts, all their actions drilled, they attack the situation swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Roger's hurt mid-deck! Bleeding bad!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He's yours, Tank!

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: We got a fire in here!

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Coming in! As he floats by the window hatch, fighting the smoke, he glances outside -- and freezes in horror:

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Oh shit!!! (shouting) We lost Ikon and Ethan!

dialogues.speaker: SATELLITE IKON
dialogues.text: has bounced off the shuttle and is falling towards Earth. It is taking the shuttle's broken retractor arm and Ethan, in MMU, with it. It moves at what looks to be about 2 mph. It jetisons six panels in unison, leaving debris in its wake.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over radio) Help me!! Hawk flies over to Frank, sucking on an oxygen regulator.  110.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (as Hawk nods) Tank! Contain the situation! Hawk and I are going out. Frank and Hawk reach the airlock door. Jerry works frantically on the door's control panel.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hurry up! We're losing them! The airlock door opens. Hawk and Frank hurry in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium here, too. Engineers return to their stations. Sara watches in horror as the satellite drifts away from Daedalus.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Range 200 meters. It's accelerating, Miss Holland.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: They're gonna lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk and Frank finish their suit-up. They fall back into the MMUs and strap them on. Hawk hyperventilates the pure oxygen, trying to replace the nitrogen in his blood with pure 02.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How long till Ikon goes off-line?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Those missiles are heating up right now. You got five minutes, but by that time it'll be out of your range.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Anything else you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Blow the seal! The AIRLOCK SEAL BLOWS. Hawk and Frank jet out --

dialogues.speaker: INTO SPACE
dialogues.text: FIRING their MMUs' nitrogen JETS towards the fleeing satellite, side-by-side. Ikon is about two hundred feet  111. away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Latch-on Starboard. On my signal, fire all jets. They split up. Frank latches his MMU on to one side of the satellite. Hawk latches on to the other.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fire! The JETS on the two MMU's FIRE in unison, nitrogen vapor spraying out. This is a tough battle, but they're winning, gradually slowing the satellite's fall. Hawk glances at a readout on the MMU: "NITROGEN FUEL AT TEN

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: I'm at ten percent, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't let it get past five or we're not getting back to the ship. They both release their fingers from the jet triggers. They look up towards the shuttle for a reference. They have stopped the satellite.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: She's static.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Houston, we've arrested the fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A collective exhale, a collective cheer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Attaboy, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hovers over Ethan, still in his MMU, pinned in by the damaged grappling arm. Frank releases the arm, pushes it away and peers inside Ethan's face-plate, sees movement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He's out.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Throw me the other payload assist modules. I'1l hook them up while  112. you bring Johnny Quest back to the ship. Frank looks at the empty pallet... then into space, sees the two PAM rockets floating away, irretrievable.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We got a problem. We only have one rocket.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One P.A.M.'s not gonna get this thing into orbit, Frank! Without active course correction the damn thing'1l go in a circle like a boat with one oar in the water! Hawk looks at the satellite, sees that two of the solar panels are crumpled like tin foil.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: (to Frank) You got another problem. Frank looks over, sees the broken panels.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Shit. Even if we do get her up, she can't power herself with two broken panels. Frank looks down at Earth, sighs, flustered, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Bring the kid back. Let me take care of this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And how exactly are you gonna take care of this, professor? You're a pilot. Hawk propels over to a panel on the satellite, pops it open.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Stand back! Blowing solar panels!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hawk, what are you -- ?! He's interrupted by a MUFFLED EXPLOSION as the giant solar panels blow off. Frank stares at Hawk, dumbfounded, but he knows what Hawk's got planned.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
dialogues.text: Throw me your auxiliary 02 module.  113. Frank won't. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HAWK
